At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Senior Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Jim Bombassei. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for taking the time to join us for our December quarter earnings call. Listening from Los Angeles is our Chairman Emeritus, Sumner Redstone. And joining us in New York are Philippe Dauman, our Executive Chairman, Pres
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for taking the time to join us for our December quarter earnings call. Listening from Los Angeles is our Chairman Emeritus, Sumner Redstone. And joining us in New York are Philippe Dauman, our Executive Chairman, President and CEO; Tom Dooley, our Chief Operating Officer; and Wade Davis, our Chief Financial Officer. 
Please note that in addition to our press release, we have slides and trending schedules containing supplemental information available on our website. I want to refer you to Page #2 in the web presentation and remind you that certain statements made on this call are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in more detail in our filings with the SEC. Today's remarks will focus on adjusted results. Reconciliations for non-GAAP financial information discussed on this call can be found in our earnings release or on our website. 
And now I'll turn a call over to Philippe.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's First Quarter Results. First, I want to thank my colleague, mentor and friend, Sumner, who's listening on the phone for his vision, his guidance and his inspiration,
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's First Quarter Results. First, I want to thank my colleague, mentor and friend, Sumner, who's listening on the phone for his vision, his guidance and his inspiration, all of which will continue to energize us with Sumner as our Chairman Emeritus. I'm honored to be the new Executive Chairman of Viacom, and I will do my utmost to continue to drive Viacom's operations forward and restore our stock to its proper evaluation, but more on that later in my remarks. 
Now let's take a quick look at the numbers. In the first quarter, revenues declined 6% to $3.15 billion. Adjusted operating income was $839 million, and adjusted net earnings from continuing operations were $470 million. Adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations declined 9% to $1.18 per diluted share. 
2015 was a challenging year for Viacom as it was from many in the industry. However, it was a watershed year in which we took many important steps to position Viacom for the future. We reorganized and refocused our organization, increasing both our Media Networks and Filmed Entertainment production pipelines. We also stepped up our investment in data measurement and marketing expertise and fueled our growth in the most attractive overseas markets. And we did all of this while delivering record earnings per share in 2015 and the highest Media Networks revenue in our history. 
As we turn the corner into 2016, the hard work and investment is bearing fruit. Let me give you a few of the highlights. We have dynamic new leadership in our business units and several of our major networks, including MTV and VH1. Viacom's creative culture is stronger than ever. Our focus on original programming and rapid deployment is paying off. Existing hits such as Lip Sync Battle, PAW Patrol, Love and Hip-hop; and exciting new programming like Game Shakers, Younger Teachers and I love Kellie Pickler are continuing to attract valuable and devoted audiences. In fact, Viacom had 7 of the top 20 cable series in the quarter. Most major networks have seen year-over-year range improvements, and that ratings strength is driving advertising improvement. There will be more to come as the change is under way at Comedy Central and MTV kick in and the ad market continues to strengthen. An enhanced distribution ecosystem is coming together with strong upside for content providers. We are experimenting and reaping the benefits of increased consumer choice. Our international business is a strong performer with great upside but remains underappreciated. We are expanding distribution, creating differentiated and popular content, building on Channel 5's substantial successes, launching a high-margin Paramount Channel to even more territories and building our success in India's high-growth market. And Paramount is into its rebuilding process with the movie pipeline improving and TV operations off to a strong start. Already, we've seen solid critical response in box office performance from the first quarter releases, and there is much more to come throughout the year. 
Turning to the Media Networks results. Revenues declined 3% to $2.75 billion in the quarter, including a 1% adverse impact of foreign exchange. Before we move on to discuss our advertising results in detail, I'd like to spend a moment to discuss the wide-ranging and innovative agreement with Snapchat that we announced this morning. The deal is important for a number of reasons, not the least of which is added as indicative of the flexible and innovative approach we are taking to grow our digital and mobile expertise rapidly and at a global scale. As part of the deal, we'll bring 2 new high-profile channels to Snapchat Discover, a Comedy Central international channel and an MTV channel in the U.S. These, on top of our other successful Discovery channels, make is one of the largest publishers on Snapchat Discovery. Importantly, Viacom will also become the external ad sales representative for Snapchat's advertising inventory, giving us the chance to offer even more value to our clients. In addition, validating the continuing cultural influence of our programming, Snapchat will increase the number of live stories it publishes tied to Viacom temple events, such as the VMAs, the EMAs, be BET Awards and others. Snapchat's immersive and extremely popular video platform aligns perfectly with our leadership in both premium long- and short-form storytelling with these same audiences. This deal between Viacom and Snapchat is a major step forward in the evolution of the marketplace, made possible by our shared focus on young audiences and Viacom's content expertise, proprietary targeting, custom marketing solutions, industry-leading sales force and our global strength. It's a great partnership for both companies and is indicative of more innovation to come. 
Looking back on the quarter. Domestic ad sales declined 4% in the quarter, a substantial sequential improvement from the prior quarter. Continued ratings games based on the content investment we made over the last few years across our channel groups are driving this positive momentum. Most of our networks are performing well and are making meaningful contributions as audience levels build. Excluding the performance of Comedy Central and MTV, our domestic television ad sales growth was solidly positive. Once ratings of MTV and Comedy Central turn around and that work is well underway, the rebound will be even more clear. And the rebound will be fueled by Viacom's continuing leadership and delivery of the most progressive and innovative solutions in the marketplace. We recently announced an update to our proprietary Echo platform, which measures the effectiveness of custom-created social marketing campaigns. We'll go to the upfront with expanded offerings in Vantage, and clients are already embracing the new Velocity content network, harnessing Velocity's creative and production resources to create data-driven, branded content programs distributed across social platforms for advertising partners. 
Domestic affiliate revenues are substantially flat in the quarter with positive organic growth, offset by the timing of content available to certain digital distributors. Absent that impact, domestic affiliate revenues grew in the low mid-single digits. With the majority of our description agreements locked into long-term deals, we had no large renewals in the quarter. However, we continue to work closely with these partners to develop new avenues for viewers to enjoy Viacom programming. To date, our authenticated sites and apps reached 75% of the subscriber universe, and in the quarter, we launched robust Apple TV apps for Nickelodeon, Nick Jr., Comedy Central and MTV and apps on Roku for MTV and Nick Jr. Viacom is currently in negotiations to extend our distribution agreement with the DISH, with whom we have a long and productive relationship. We have entered into a short-term extension with them as we hammer out the details of our long-term renewal. There may be short-term hiccups along the way, but we firmly believe that we will ultimately reach an agreement that will be productive for both sides. 
It has been a strong quarter for many of our individual networks, each of which has become more flexible, more aggressive and more entrepreneurial. There's greater sharing of strategies and best practices across the house, which enhances our ability to make the most of the unprecedented amount of high-quality original programming we are rolling  out. 
Original programming is key to reducing viewer fatigue, provides greater opportunities for advertiser integration, brings value in secondary markets and reinforces our network's cultural impact at the virtual and the real world watercooler. There's no better example of this than Nickelodeon, our biggest brand. In the first quarter, Nick's ratings improved over the prior year, and in the current quarter, we are looking at greater gains. Nickelodeon is the 2-11 leader in total day ratings and has been its nearest competitor for 26 weeks straight in this demo. In fact, nick's lead over the competition continued to widen the corner with Nickelodeon's 30% ahead of Disney and 78% ahead of Cartoon Network. We had the #1 and #2 kids series in the quarter. Nick's newest preschool hit, Blaze and the Monster Machines, ranked #1 across TV with kids 2-5, posting gains of 47% from a year ago. PAW Patrol continued strength in second place. This year, Nick Animation celebrates its 25th anniversary, and its creative culture has never been more vibrant. In the quarter, Nick owned the top 3 animated shows on TV with kids 2-11. Alvin, SpongeBob SquarePants and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. A new season of the Turtles kicked off last month, and we'll have new episodes from SpongeBob, The Fairly Odd Parents, Alvin, Harpy Beats, Sandra and Craig, Cricket, Rabbits and Miraculous throughout the quarter. And next month, Lake Shelton will be hosting the Kids Choice Awards, Nickelodeon's most important temple. 
VH1 is another turnaround story that we're extremely excited about. Under new leadership, the network has reversed earlier ratings declines, and that positive momentum is accelerating faster than any other Viacom brand. VH1's first quarter primetime ratings in the 18-49 demo were up 5% in the quarter. Range are up by stunning 40%. VH1 is now the #1 primetime cable network on Mondays among adults 18-49 and the top 10 cable network overall in that demo. Driven by 11 Hip-Hop and Black Crew franchises, VH1 had 4 of the top 20 original cable series in the first quarter, and the network is expanding on this success, increasing its output of original programming through additional night per week. 
TV Land C3 ratings were also up in the quarter as smart acquisitions drove sequential higher viewership each month. As we move to the current quarter, TV Land's high-quality original programming is already hitting with a season 2 premiere of Younger, driving 78% higher ratings than the season 1 series premier. In addition, Teachers, the critically acclaimed new comedy, has gotten off to a solid start. As we move through the quarter, the network will debut the single comedy Lopez, starring George Lopez; and the final season of the Soul Men, featuring Cedric the Entertainer and Nash. 
BET also benefited from the steady investment of distinctive content. It continues to build momentum and exhibits strong ratings growth. The network has reversed significant challenges in 2015, culminating in double-digit ratings growth in the first quarter. BET is now the #16 ad-supported cable network amongst adults 18-49, up from number 20 a year ago. And it's the only network among the top 20 to post double-digit ratings gains over last year. BET remains the #1 cable TV network among African-Americans. 
We're proud of what the BET team has done and how quickly they're reaping the rewards of the targeted investments in programming we've made. The best is yet to come at BET, and we're looking forward to continued growth as the network continues its evolution. 
Viacom had a solid first quarter with premieres of Ink Master drawing higher ratings and the Bar Rescue franchise showing continued strength and growth. Spike hit its second season of Lip Sync Battle with its first holiday special, which delivered almost 2 million viewers and was the #1 entertainment show in cable with all viewers 18-49 as well as women 18-49. Joseph Gordon Levitt's performance of Rhythm Nation has become a pop-culture sensation now with 10 million views on YouTube and growing. 
Moving to the current quarter. The official season 2 premiere of Lip Sync Battle shattered ratings and digital records for the network. The one-hour special drew 4.7 million viewers, making it the most-watched original series episode in Spike history. The season 2 debut is the #1 ranked show in all of television in the time slot with adults 18-49 and adults 18-34 as well as women 18-49 and women 18-34. The season 2 premiere has been viewed over 55 million times on various digital platforms. To date, Lip Sync Battle content overall secured 0.5 billion views across all platforms. Lip Sync Battle is without a doubt a global phenomenon. The U.S. version of the program can now be seen in 120 countries and territories worldwide. The format is also under license in 130 [ph] territories, most recently debuting in China where 30 million people viewed the program online in its first weekend. In addition, we have already launched the format on Channel 5 in the U.K. with great success where it's averaging a 22% share among viewers 16-34. 
Comedy Central remains a force with men 18-34 with 4 of the top 25 cable entertainment series in the quarter. South Park showed continued strength and ranked #2 in that demo, and the Daily Show of Trevor Noah was the most-watched late-night talk show for this valuable audience as well as with adults 18-24. The story of the Daily Show is strong, with 3 consecutive months of growth with total viewers and video consumption, including a robust 3 million full episodes starting each week across digital platforms. Trevor Noah has proven to be a star, and it will continue to build on the strong start especially with valuable young audiences across multiple platforms. Historically, The Daily Show sees double-digit increases in the presidential election year, so we believe even better results are ahead. 
And soft spot from schedule and ongoing consumption shifts to under-measured platforms resulted in gentle challenging ratings overall, but I have great confidence Comedy Central will overcome these issues. The recent renewals of Insight and Broad City are continuing evidence that the network is on solid creative footing and remains the first choice for today's hottest comedy talent. We're already seeing a rebound. Ratings in the second half of the quarter began to improve led by a new season of Workaholics and the series premiere of Idiot Sitter. In addition, tonight, Comedy Central will kick off a new season of Touch Point Oh and premiere Not Safe with Nikki Glaser, a new very naughty and very funny series from a popular comedian. 
Despite several bright spots, MTV experienced a difficult first quarter overall. Scripted originals still ranked at the top of their time periods, but ratings were lower than expected. As MTV moved into the second quarter, 2 of the network's best-performing franchises, Teen Mom and Teen Wolf, returned to strong [indiscernible] ratings in the premiere of the epic fantasy series, the Shannara Chronicles drew 7.5 million viewers across all telecast. MTV's development process didn't adapt quickly enough to the shifting preferences of its audiences. We're fixing that by accelerating its development pipeline and returning its best series in faster cycles. The network's new management is deep in a turnaround plan and has already greenlit several new series with 4 slated for fiscal 2016. I have complete confidence that MTV is headed in the right direction. 
Outside the U.S., our footprint continues to grow, with launches of TeenNick in Italy, BET in France and Comedy Central in the Czech Republic and Norway. In addition, Viacom International Media Networks will be launching the Paramount Channel in Italy at the end of the month. Paramount Channel continues to be a good, strategic business for us. It's already profitable and allows us to further monetize its own content at minimal incremental cost. As you know, India has been an area of great focus and thoughtful investment for Viacom. It is the world's leading growth market and a country where we are growing our revenues and growing our share. In the mass entertainment category, COLORS is now established itself as the top ranked urban channel in India. MTV is #1 in the youth of genre, Nickelodeon is #1 with kids and VH1 is the #1 English entertainment network. Our India channels are quickly building large, dedicated audiences and there are very exciting opportunities to come. 
Paramount closed the first quarter with the 2 December releases that have exceeded expectations. Daddy's Home, starting Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg, has already earned more than $210 million at the global box office. And the five-time Academy Award Nominee, The Big Short, continues to win accolades, including the top honors at the Producers Guild Awards. It's a good start to an important year for Paramount, one where we will once again make full use of our exceptional infrastructure and talent. Coming up this weekend, Paramount will be releasing the highly-anticipated Zoolander 2, which has been generating great buzz for months. Later in the quarter, we'll have Whiskey Tango Foxtrot featuring Tina Fey and producer JJ Abrams' 10 Cloverfield Lane. Looking through the end of 2016, Paramount will be releasing Star Trek Beyond also from producer JJ Abrams, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Out of the Shadows from producer Michael Bay and the reimagining of the classic Benhur. And next fiscal year, Paramount's full slate will include all-new Jack Reacher starting Tom Cruise, Paramount Animation's Monster Trust and an epic thriller directed by Robert Zumeckis and starring Brad Pitt. 
Paramount Television's quarter also started out strong with the live production of Grease on FOX. The telecast is a hit with critics and audiences and delivered more than 14 million live viewers in the U.S. Paramount is a very valuable and significantly undervalued part of Viacom. Its library of hit films generate significant recurring income year-after-year. It has been from a historical standpoint in a brief income slump due in part to a recent low number of theatrical releases, which reduces the positive waterfall impact of prior year film releases. This will change now that we are back on track to release approximately 15 high-quality releases a year, including numerous temples. At the same time, what is now a low-cost startup television production operation, we'll ramp up the profitability over the next few years. Once we get through this rebuilding process and related investment, we expect Paramount to pump out significant operating income and free cash flow in the years to come. At the same time, its content will provide the fuel for EPIX in the U.S., a growing number of Paramount channels outside of the U.S. and will serve as an important source of television content for Media Networks, including Nickelodeon, Spike and MTV. 
In conclusion, I want to address the speculation about Viacom and our future. Our outlook and the facts has been distorted and obscured by the naysayers, self-interested critics and publicity seekers. We will not be distracted or deterred as we build for the bright future ahead of us. As Executive Chairman and CEO, I will continue to work tirelessly to secure that future and will leave no stone unturned either tactically or strategically. Sumner and I have more than a 30-year history side-by-side building his media empire. He and the board of Viacom believing in my abilities and my character have entrusted me with weighty responsibilities, none of which are inconsistent or incompatible. My singular objective is to protect and build value for all of Viacom shareholders and in doing so, for all the beneficiaries of Sumner's trust that not only include the his daughter but also those of her brother. And finally, let me be absolutely clear, I could not be more focused on getting Viacom stock price back to the much higher level enjoyed under my leadership just a short time ago. No one should doubt my resolve or the resolve of our entire management team in making that happen. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Wade.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our December quarter are available on our website. Now let's take a look at our segment results.
componenttext:
Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our December quarter are available on our website. 
Now let's take a look at our segment results. At our Media Networks segment, revenues in the quarter were down 3% compared to the prior year. Domestic revenues decreased 3%, and international revenues declined 4%. Excluding the 7% unfavorable impact from foreign currency, the international revenues were up 3%, reflecting growth in advertising and affiliate revenues. 
Page 9 of our web deck provides a breakdown of our Media Networks' revenue performance. In terms of advertising, worldwide revenues declined to 3% in the quarter. Domestic revenues were down 4%, and international revenues were down 2%. Excluding foreign exchange, which had an 8 percentage point unfavorable impact, international advertising grew 6%, driven by growth in Europe. In terms of affiliate revenues, worldwide revenues were down 1%. Domestic revenues were substantially flat in the quarter, while international revenues declined 6%. Domestic affiliate revenues were unfavorably impacted by the timing of product available under certain distribution agreements. 
Foreign exchange had a 9 percentage point unfavorable impact on international affiliate revenue growth. Ancillary revenues were down 19%, driven by lower consumer products revenue, reflecting comparisons to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles merchandise sale in the December quarter of last year as well as the decline in television syndication revenue. Expenses decreased 3% in the quarter. Within operating expenses, programming expenses were down 3%, while distribution and other expenses decreased 4%. SG&A expense decreased 2% in the quarter. The decreases in programming and SG&A cost were principally due to the savings from our strategic realignment last year. 
Media Networks' adjusted operating income was down 4% for the quarter, and the adjusted operating income margin was 41%. The decline in operating income was driven by the revenue decline of 3%, partially offset either 3% decline in expenses. 
Moving to Filmed Entertainment. Revenues were down 15% in the quarter principally due to decreases in theatrical and home entertainment revenues, partially offset by an increase in license fees. Foreign exchange had a 3 percentage point unfavorable impact on Filmed Entertainment revenue growth. Page 12 of the web presentation provides a breakdown of Filmed Entertainment revenues. 
Theatrical revenues declined 44%. The decline in revenues was due to lower carryover revenues given the difficult comparison to the strong performance of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles in the December quarter of last year as well as lower revenues from our current quarterly leases. Out of our more significant releases, The Big Short and Daddy's Home, were both released in December of this year compared to Interstellar, which was released earlier in last year's December quarter. Home Entertainment revenues declined 24%, reflecting lower carryover revenues due to comparisons to Transformers: Age of Extinction in the December quarter of last year. 
Revenue from license fees increased 25%, primarily driven of licensing of certain titles in subscription video-on-demand and television. Filmed Entertainment generated an adjusted operating loss of $146 million in the quarter as compared to a loss of $60 million last year. The decrease in operating results reflects the timing and mix of current quarterly leases as well as lower contributions in prior-period releases. 
Now moving beyond the segment results. The other items line reflect a gain of $2 million versus an $18 million loss in the December quarter of last year. Last year's loss was principally due to foreign exchange. 
In terms of taxes, the adjusted effective tax rate was 32.8%, reflecting a 50 basis point increase as compared to prior year. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed. For the quarter, we had cash used of $152 million, which compares to $57 million of free cash flow
componenttext:
Thanks, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed. For the quarter, we had cash used of $152 million, which compares to $57 million of free cash flow in the December quarter of last year. Page 5 of the web presentation provides the components of free cash flow. The decline in free cash flow versus the prior year is principally due to higher working capital utilizations and lower operating income. Working capital was negatively impacted by the timing of film receivables from home entertainment and television. 
Moving on to our debt. That remains principally fixed rate, with an average gross at the end of the quarter of 4.6%. We ended the quarter with $12.6 billion [ph] of total debt and $327 million cash and cash equivalents. At the end of the quarter, our leverage ratio was 3.2x. We have $368 million remaining outstanding of our 6.25% senior notes, which mature on April 30. We plan on paying these notes off. 
Now let's turn to some of the factors impacting fiscal 2016. In terms of affiliate revenues, quarterly affiliate revenue will fluctuate according to the timing of transactions and the recognition of revenue related to certain distribution agreements, which are tied to product availability. For the fiscal year 2016, we expect growth in affiliate revenues to be in the low mid-single-digit range. For the full year, we expect that Media Networks' programming expense growth rate will be in the mid-single digits. In terms of taxes, for 2016, we are forecasting a book tax rate of approximately 32.5%. We will refine this as we go through the year and get a better sense of the domestic-international profitability mix. 
At Paramount, we are excited about the upcoming slate, including our summer temples, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 2 and Star Trek 3. For fiscal 2016, we expect profits to be weighted to the back half of the year as the studio benefit from their summer releases. Looking ahead of the studio's production and development pipeline. Paramount has just wrapped production on Jack Reacher 2. This month, the studio is commencing production on 4 major films: Scarlet will star in Ghost in the Shell, which is in partnership with DreamWorks. Baywatch, starring Dwayne Johnson and Zach Efron, the newest chapter in Vin Diesel's action franchise XXX 3: The Return of Vander Cage in the romantic thriller set in World War II, which is directed by Robert Zemeckis and stars Brad Pitt and Marion Cotillard. In the spring, the studio goes production on the Academy award-winning filmmaker, Alexander Payne's next movie called Downsizing starring Matt Damon. 
In summary, while last year we experienced broad ratings weaknesses, we took organizational and creative steps to address those challenges. The progress we began to see at the end of fiscal 2015 is continuing. In the December quarter, 6 of our top 10 network saw growth in ratings. In March quarter-to-date, we are seeing ratings growth for our overall portfolio of Media Networks. At Paramount, they have started the fiscal year with several successes at the box office, and we look forward to the summer temple releases. In terms of our international Media Networks, we are benefiting from our investment over the past several years and anticipate strong double-digit growth in profits this year. The acquisition of Channel 5 has been an unqualified success. And the continued launch of new networks in Europe, Latin America and Africa has enabled us to build and grow our scale in the most important developing and developed markets. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to your questions. Operator?

componenttext: Well, look, yes, Sumner and I have been in harmony in how we pursue our strategy going forward. Obviously, as we all know, the world is changing. Our specific industry is changing. We have taken a significant number of steps, which I outlined in my remarks, I won't repeat it, to move into the future, to build the existing ecosystem, revitalize our brands, grow internationally, grow on multiple platforms. The Snapchat deal that we announced this morning is an indicator. You will see more deals to come. As I said in my remarks, I will leave no stone unturned. I never have and I never will. And our objective is to build value. We are building value for the long term. We're building value with a view to getting a better valuation of our stock in the short term. But we will not take actions that undermine that value. And we believe that with consistency in leadership, consistency in purpose, driving our content around the world, the across multiple platforms, finding new source of revenues in licensing, consumer products and other areas, we will get Viacom back to the growth that we all want to see.

componenttext: We're seeing strong demand in the scatter market and strong pricing. We're seeing pricing in the scatter market over the last upside in the neighborhood of 20%. So that bodes very well for the upcoming upfront, but bodes particularly well for us is that the great progress that we're making across most of our networks, which I believe will turn into virtually all of our networks in short order. We are seeing great appetite for our leading Viacom Vantage, Viacom Echo and Viacom Velocity products. We are determined to get back to ad growth. We've also looked at having a healthy environment for our marketing partners. As you know, we have taken down our ad load in several key time periods across several of our networks. And that, to some extent, might have suppressed some of the short-term advertising brought, but I think it is healthy for us and will lead to very healthy return to ad growth as we improve over the back half of the year and into next year.

componenttext: Rich, first of all, as far as the performance of Viacom, let me just challenge what you indicated. Viacom's performance was at the top. In fact, we had 5 consecutive years of being -- significantly beating the S&P in our stock performance. Clearly, we have fallen back a lot in the last 2 and especially last year. Some of the decline was accentuated in the recent past by a lot of noise that existed around us. And I think some people who have been buying the stock in that period have the foresight to see through the noise. And I think we have outlined the steps we're taking, the forward-looking steps we are taking and the progress we're making in several aspects of our operations. And then I leave it to the board. I'm gratified that the board overwhelmingly supported me for the position. They know me. They know what our plans are, strategic plans. They know what our operational plans. They endorsed them, they have confidence in them and I will repay back that confidence by producing the results without shirking our obligation to make the changes that are necessary to make Viacom the leading content company of the future. That is our objective. As far as your question relating to Comcast, yes, they have violated our agreements, and we are going to not sit back. We have not filed a lawsuit against Comcast, but we will preserve our rights as we go forward.

componenttext: Thank you, Wassily. Look, we are -- let me take it into parts. As far as Comedy Central goes, clearly, we have great creative output there that's resonating with our audiences. We have a number of returning series that are coming on-stream to add to what's already there. So I think we have a healthy pipeline of Comedy Central, and I think over time, that will take care of itself. And it's very attractive programming that reaches young audiences and attractive to advertisers. As far as MTV goes, MTV is more of a rebuilding mode. We have a new Head of MTV that started just a very few months ago who has revamped his team, has, as I mentioned in my remarks, bring that new series. We need -- needed and need more programming on MTV. Now that will start kicking in over time. We are accelerating the airing of the shows that are already in production so that we can fill the schedule better. We're going to add new shows, and that will just build on itself over the next several months and quarters. So it's a little bit of a different exercise there. But I think the energy that's being applied to it, the new enthusiasm for it, the reaching out to more programming sources and more relevant programming sources is very encouraging, and I feel very good about the future there.

componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for taking the time to join us for our December Quarter Earnings Call. 
Listening from Los Angeles is our Chairman Emeritus, Sumner Redstone. And joining us in New York are Philippe Dauman, our Executive Chairman, President and CEO; Tom Dooley, our Chief Operating Officer; and Wade Davis, our Chief Financial Officer.
Please note that, in addition to our press release, we have slides and trending schedules containing supplemental information available on our website. I want to refer you to Page #2 in the web presentation and remind you that certain statements made on this call are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in more detail in our filings with the SEC. Today's remarks will focus on adjusted results. Reconciliations for non-GAAP financial information discussed on this call can be found in our earnings release or on our website.
And now I'll turn a call over to Philippe.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's first quarter results.First, I want to thank my colleague, mentor and friend Sumner, who is listening on the phone, for his vision, his guidance and his inspiration
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's first quarter results.
First, I want to thank my colleague, mentor and friend Sumner, who is listening on the phone, for his vision, his guidance and his inspiration, all of which will continue to energize us with Sumner as our Chairman Emeritus. I am honored to be the new Executive Chairman of Viacom, and I will do my utmost to continue to drive Viacom's operations forward and restore our stock to its proper valuation, but more on that later in my remarks.
Now let's take a quick look at the numbers. In the first quarter, revenues declined 6% to $3.15 billion. Adjusted operating income was $839 million, and adjusted net earnings from continuing operations were $470 million. Adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations declined 9% to $1.18 per diluted share.
2015 was a challenging year for Viacom, as it was for many in the industry. However, it was a watershed year in which we took many important steps to position Viacom for the future. We reorganized and refocused our organization, increasing both our Media Networks and Filmed Entertainment production pipelines. We also stepped up our investment in data measurement and marketing expertise and fueled our growth in the most attractive overseas markets. And we did all of this while delivering record earnings per share in 2015 and the highest Media Networks revenue in our history. As we turn the corner into 2016, the hard work and investment is bearing fruit. Let me give you a few of the highlights.
We have dynamic, new leadership in our business units and several of our major networks, including MTV and VH1. Viacom's creative culture is stronger than ever. Our focus on original programming and rapid deployment is paying off. Existing hits such as Lip Sync Battle, PAW Patrol, Love & Hip Hop; and exciting new programming like Game Shakers, Younger, Teachers and I Love Kellie Pickler are continuing to attract valuable and devoted audiences. In fact, Viacom had 7 of the top 20 cable series in the quarter. Most major networks have seen year-over-year range improvement, and that ratings strength is driving advertising improvement. There will be more to come as the changes underway at Comedy Central and MTV kick in and the ad market continues to strengthen.
An enhanced distribution ecosystem is coming together, with strong upside for content providers. We are experimenting and reaping the benefits of increased consumer choice. Our international business is a strong performer with great upside but remains underappreciated. We are expanding distribution, creating differentiated and popular content, building on Channel 5's substantial successes, launching the high-margin Paramount Channel to even more territories and building our success in India's high-growth market. And Paramount is into its rebuilding process, with the movie pipeline improving and TV operations off to a strong start. Already, we've seen solid critical response in box office performance from the first quarter releases, and there is much more to come throughout the year.
Turning to the Media Networks results. Revenues declined 3% to $2.57 billion in the quarter, including a 1% adverse impact of foreign exchange.
Before we move on to discuss our advertising results in detail, I'd like to spend a moment to discuss the wide-ranging and innovative agreement with Snapchat that we announced this morning. The deal is important for a number of reasons, not the least of which is that it is indicative of the flexible and innovative approach we are taking to grow our digital and mobile expertise rapidly and at a global scale. As part of the deal, we will bring 2 new high-profile channels to Snapchat Discover: a Comedy Central international channel and an MTV channel in the U.S. These, on top of our other successful discovery channels, make us one of the largest publishers on Snapchat Discover. Importantly, Viacom will also become the external ad sales representative for Snapchat's advertising inventory, giving us the chance to offer even more value to our clients. In addition, validating the continuing cultural influence of our programming, Snapchat will increase the number of Live Stories it publishes, tied to Viacom's tentpole events such as the VMAs, the EMAs, the BET awards and others. Snapchat's immersive and extremely popular short-form video platform aligns perfectly with our leadership in both premium long- and short-form storytelling for these same audiences.
This deal between Viacom and Snapchat is a major step forward in the evolution of the marketplace, made possible by our shared focus on young audiences; and Viacom's content expertise, proprietary targeting, custom marketing solutions, industry-leading sales force; and our global strength. It's a great partnership for both companies and is indicative of more innovation to come.
Looking back on the quarter. Domestic ad sales declined 4% in the quarter, a substantial sequential improvement from the prior quarter. Continued ratings gains based on the content investment we made over the last few years across our channel groups are driving this positive momentum. Most of our networks are performing well and are making meaningful contributions as audience levels build. Excluding the performance of Comedy Central and MTV, our domestic television ad sales growth was solidly positive. Once ratings at MTV and Comedy Central turn around, and that work is well underway, the rebound will be even more clear. And the rebound will be fueled by Viacom's continuing leadership in delivery of the most progressive and innovative solutions in the marketplace.
We recently announced an update to our proprietary Echo platform which measures the effectiveness of custom-created social marketing campaigns. We'll go to the upfront with expanded offerings in Vantage. And clients are already embracing the new Velocity content network harnessing Velocity's creative and production resources to create data-driven, branded content programs distributed across social platforms for advertising partners.
Domestic affiliate revenues are substantially flat in the quarter, with positive organic growth offset by the timing of content available to certain digital distributors. Absent that impact, domestic affiliate revenues grew in the low mid-single digits. With the majority of our distribution agreements locked in to long-term deals, we had no large renewals in the quarter. However, we continue to work closely with these partners to develop new avenues for viewers to enjoy Viacom programming. To date, our authenticated sites and apps reach 75% of the subscriber universe. And in the quarter, we launched robust Apple TV apps for Nickelodeon, Nick Jr., Comedy Central and MTV; and apps on Roku for MTV and Nick Jr. Viacom is currently in negotiations to extend our distribution agreement with DISH, with whom we have a long and productive relationship. We have entered into a short-term extension with them as we hammer out the details of a long-term renewal. There may be short-term hiccups along the way, but we firmly believe that we will ultimately reach an agreement that will be productive for both sides. It has been a strong quarter for many of our individual networks, each of which has become more flexible, more aggressive and more entrepreneurial. There is greater sharing of strategies and best practices across the house, which enhances our ability to make the most of the unprecedented amount of high-quality original programming we are rolling out.
Original programming is key to reducing viewer fatigue, provides greater opportunities for advertiser integration, brings value in secondary markets and reinforces our network's cultural impact at the virtual and the real world watercooler. There is no better example of this than Nickelodeon, our biggest brand. In the first quarter, Nick's ratings improved over the prior year, and in the current quarter, we are looking at greater gains. Nickelodeon is the 2 to 11 leader in total day ratings and has been its nearest competitor for 26 weeks straight in this demo. In fact, Nick's lead over the competition continued to widen in the quarter, with Nickelodeon 30% ahead of Disney and 78% ahead of Cartoon Network. We had the #1 and #2 kids series in the quarter. Nick's newest preschool hit, Blaze and the Monster Machines, ranked #1 across TV with kids 2 to 5, posting gains of 47% from a year ago. PAW Patrol continued its strength in second place.
This year, Nick animation celebrates its 25th anniversary, and its creative culture has never been more vibrant. In the quarter, Nick owned the top 3 animated shows on TV with kids 2 to 11: ALVINNN!!!, SpongeBob SquarePants and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. A new season of Turtles kicked off last month. And we'll have new episodes from SpongeBob, The Fairly Odd Parents, ALVINNN!!!, Harvey Beaks, Sanjay & Craig, Pig Goat Banana Cricket, Rabbids and Miraculous throughout the quarter. And next month, Blake Shelton will be hosting the Kids' Choice Awards, Nickelodeon's most important tentpole.
VH1 is another turnaround story that we're extremely excited about. Under new leadership, the network has reversed earlier ratings declines, and that positive momentum is accelerating faster than in any other Viacom brand. VH1's first quarter prime time ratings in the 18 to 49 demo were up 5%, and in the quarter, ratings were up a stunning 40%. VH1 is now the #1 prime time cable network on Mondays among adults 18 to 49 and a top 10 cable network overall in that demo. Driven by the Love & Hip Hop and Black Ink Crew franchises, VH1 had 4 of the top 20 original cable series in the first quarter. And the network is expanding on this success, increasing its output of original programming through an additional night per week.
TV Land C3 ratings were also up in the quarter, as smart acquisitions drove sequentially higher viewership each month. As we move to the current quarter, TV Land's high-quality original programming is already hitting, with the season 2 premiere of Younger driving 78% higher ratings than the season 1 series premier. In addition, Teachers, the critically acclaimed new comedy, has gotten off to a solid start. As we move through the quarter, the network will debut the single-cam comedy Lopez, starring George Lopez; and the final season of The Soul Man, featuring Cedric the Entertainer and Niecy Nash.
BET also benefited from the steady investment of distinctive content. It continues to build momentum and exhibits strong ratings growth. The network has reversed significant challenges in 2015, culminating in double-digit ratings growth in the first quarter. BET is now the #16 ad-supported cable network among adults 18 to 49, up from #20 a year ago. And it's the only network among the top 20 to post double-digit ratings gains over last year. BET remains the #1 cable TV network among African-Americans. We're proud of what the BET team has done and how quickly they are reaping the rewards of the targeted investments in programming we've made. The best is yet to come at BET, and we're looking forward to continued growth as the network continues its evolution.
Spike had a solid first quarter with premieres of Ink Master drawing higher ratings and the Bar Rescue franchise showing continued strength and growth. Spike teased its second season of Lip Sync Battle with its first holiday special, which delivered almost 2 million viewers and was the #1 entertainment show in cable with all viewers 18 to 49 as well as women 18 to 49. Joseph Gordon-Levitt's performance of Rhythm Nation has become a pop culture sensation, now with 10 million views on YouTube and growing. Moving to the current quarter, the official season 2 premiere of Lip Sync Battle shattered ratings and digital records for the network. The 1-hour special drew 4.7 million viewers, making it the most-watched original series episode in Spike history. The season 2 debut is the #1 ranked show in all of television in the time slot with adults 18 to 49 and adults 18 to 34 as well as women 18 to 49 and women 18 to 34. The season 2 premiere has been viewed over 55 million times on various digital platforms. To date, Lip Sync Battle content overall secured 0.5 billion views across all platforms. Lip Sync Battle is without a doubt a global phenomenon. The U.S. version of the program can now be seen in 120 countries and territories worldwide. The format is also under license in 130 territories, most recently debuting in China where 30 million people viewed the program online in its first weekend. In addition, we have already launched the format on Channel 5 in the U.K., to great success, where it is averaging a 22% share among viewers 16 to 34.
Comedy Central remains a force with men 18 to 34, with 4 of the top 25 cable entertainment series in the quarter. South Park showed continued strength and ranked #2 in that demo. And The Daily Show with Trevor Noah was the most-watched late-night talk show for this valuable audience as well as with adults 18 to 24. The story of The Daily Show is strong with 3 consecutive months of growth with total viewers and video consumption, including a robust 3 million full-episode starts each week across digital platforms. Trevor Noah has proven to be a star, and he will continue to build on the strong start especially with valuable young audiences across multiple platforms. Historically, The Daily Show sees double-digit increases in a presidential election year, so we believe even better results are ahead.
Some soft spot in the schedule and ongoing consumption shifts to under-measured platforms resulted in challenging ratings overall, but I have great confidence Comedy Central will overcome these issues. The recent renewals of Inside Amy Schumer and Broad City are continuing evidence that the network is on solid creative footing and remains the first choice for today's hottest comedy talent. We are already seeing a rebound. Ratings in the second half of the quarter began to improve, led by a new season of Workaholics and the series premiere of Idiotsitter. In addition, tonight, Comedy Central will kick off a new season of Tosh.0; and premiere Not Safe With Nikki Glaser, a new, very naughty and very funny series from a popular comedian.
Despite several bright spots, MTV experienced a difficult first quarter overall. Scripted originals still ranked at the top of their time periods, but ratings were lower than expected. As MTV moved into the second quarter, 2 of the network's best-performing franchises, Teen Mom and Teen Wolf, returned to strong LIVE+3 ratings. And the premiere of the epic fantasy series The Shannara Chronicles drew 7.5 million viewers across all telecasts. MTV's development process didn't adapt quickly enough to the shifting preferences of its audiences. We're fixing that by accelerating its development pipeline and returning its best series in faster cycles. The network's new management is deep in a turnaround plan; and has already greenlit several new series, with 4 slated for fiscal 2016. I have complete confidence that MTV is headed in the right direction.
Outside the U.S., our footprint continues to grow with launches of TeenNick in Italy, BET in France and Comedy Central in the Czech Republic and Norway. In addition, Viacom International Media Networks will be launching the Paramount Channel in Italy at the end of the month. Paramount Channel continues to be a good, strategic business for us. It is already profitable and allows us to further monetize owned content at minimal incremental cost.
As you know, India has been an area of great focus and thoughtful investment for Viacom. It is the world's leading growth market and a country where we are growing our revenues and growing our share. In the mass entertainment category, Colors has now established itself as the top-ranked urban channel in India. MTV is #1 in the youth genre. Nickelodeon is #1 with kids, and VH1 is the #1 English entertainment network. Our India channels are quickly building large, dedicated audiences; and there are very exciting opportunities to come.
Paramount closed the first quarter with 2 December releases that have exceeded expectations. Daddy's Home, starting Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg, has already earned more than $210 million at the global box office. And the 5-time Academy Award-nominated The Big Short continues to win accolades, including top honors at the Producers Guild Awards. It's a good start to an important year for Paramount, one where we will once again make full use of our exceptional infrastructure and talent. Coming up this weekend, Paramount will be releasing the highly anticipated Zoolander 2, which has been generating great buzz for months. Later in the quarter, we'll have Whiskey Tango Foxtrot, featuring Tina Fey; and producer J.J. Abrams' 10 Cloverfield Lane. Looking through the end of 2016, Paramount will be releasing Star Trek Beyond, also from producer J.J. Abrams; Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows from producer Michael Bay; and a reimagining of the classic Ben-Hur. And next fiscal year, Paramount's full slate will include an all-new Jack Reacher starring Tom Cruise, Paramount Animation's Monster Trucks and an epic thriller directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring Brad Pitt.
Paramount Television's quarter also started out strong with a live production of Grease on FOX. The telecast was a hit with critics and audiences and delivered more than 14 million LIVE+3 viewers in the U.S.
Paramount is a very valuable and significantly undervalued part of Viacom. Its library of hit films generates significant recurring income year after year. It has been, from a historical standpoint, in a brief income slump due in part to a recent low number of theatrical releases, which reduces the positive waterfall impact of prior year film releases. This will change now that we are back on track to release approximately 15 high-quality releases a year, including numerous tentpoles. At the same time, what is now a low-cost startup television production operation will ramp up the profitability over the next few years. Once we get through this rebuilding process and related investment, we expect Paramount to pump out significant operating income and free cash flow in the years to come. At the same time, its content will provide the fuel for EPIX in the U.S., a growing number of Paramount channels outside of the U.S.; and will serve as an important source of television content for Media Networks, including Nickelodeon, Spike and MTV.
In conclusion, I want to address the speculation about Viacom and our future. Our outlook and the facts have been distorted and obscured by the naysayers, self-interested critics and publicity seekers. We will not be distracted or deterred as we build for the bright future ahead of us. As Executive Chairman and CEO, I will continue to work tirelessly to secure that future and will leave no stone unturned either tactically or strategically. Sumner and I have a more than 30-year history side-by-side building his media empire. He and the board of Viacom, believing in my abilities and my character, have entrusted me with weighty responsibilities, none of which are inconsistent or incompatible. My singular objective is to protect and build value for all of Viacom shareholders and, in doing so, for all the beneficiaries of Sumner's trust not only including the descendants of his daughter but also those of her brother. And finally, let me be absolutely clear: I could not be more focused on getting Viacom's stock price back to the much higher level it enjoyed under my leadership just a short time ago. No one should doubt my resolve or the resolve of our entire management team in making that happen. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Wade.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Philippe.Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our December quarter are available on our website.Now let's take a look at our segment results.
componenttext:
Thanks, Philippe.
Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our December quarter are available on our website.
Now let's take a look at our segment results.
At our Media Networks segment, revenues in the quarter were down 3% compared with the prior year. Domestic revenues decreased 3%, and international revenues declined 4%. Excluding a 7% unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues were up 3%, reflecting growth in advertising and affiliate revenues. Page 9 of our web deck provides a breakdown of our Media Networks revenue performance.
In terms of advertising, worldwide revenues declined 3% in the quarter. Domestic revenues were down 4%, and international revenues were down 2%. Excluding foreign exchange, which had an 8 percentage point unfavorable impact, international advertising grew 6%, driven by growth in Europe. In terms of affiliate revenues, worldwide revenues were down 1%. Domestic revenues were substantially flat in the quarter, while international revenues declined 6%. Domestic affiliate revenues were unfavorably impacted by the timing of product available under certain distribution agreements. Foreign exchange had a 9 percentage point unfavorable impact on international affiliate revenue growth. Ancillary revenues were down 19%, driven by lower consumer products revenue, reflecting comparisons to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles merchandise sale in the December quarter of last year as well as the decline in television syndication revenue.
Expenses decreased 3% in the quarter. Within operating expenses, programming expenses were down 3%, while distribution and other expenses decreased 4%. SG&A expense decreased 2% in the quarter. The decreases in programming and SG&A costs were principally due to the savings from our strategic realignment last year.
Media Networks' adjusted operating income was down 4% for the quarter, and the adjusted operating income margin was 41%. The decline in operating income was driven by the revenue decline of 3%, partially offset by the 3% decline in expenses.
Moving to Filmed Entertainment. Revenues were down 15% in the quarter principally due to decreases in theatrical and home entertainment revenues, partially offset by an increase in license fees. Foreign exchange had a 3 percentage point unfavorable impact on Filmed Entertainment revenue growth. Page 12 of the web presentation provides a breakdown of Filmed Entertainment revenues.
Theatrical revenues declined 44%. The decline in revenues was due to lower carryover revenues given the difficult comparison to the strong performance of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles in the December quarter of last year, as well as lower revenues from our current-quarter releases. Of our more significant releases, The Big Short and Daddy's Home were both released in December of this year compared to Interstellar, which was released earlier in last year's December quarter. Home entertainment revenues declined 24%, reflecting lower carryover revenues due to comparisons to Transformers: Age of Extinction in the December quarter of last year. Revenue from license fees increased 25%, primarily driven by the licensing of certain titles in subscription video-on-demand and television.
Filmed Entertainment generated an adjusted operating loss of $146 million in the quarter, as compared to a loss of $60 million last year. The decrease in operating results reflects the timing and mix of current-quarter releases, as well as lower contributions from prior-period releases.
Now moving beyond the segment results. The other items line reflects a gain of $2 million versus 18 -- an $18 million loss in the December quarter of last year. Last year's loss was principally due to foreign exchange. In terms of taxes, the adjusted effective tax rate was 32.8%, reflecting a 50 basis point increase as compared to prior year.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Wade.I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed.For the quarter, we had a cash use of $152 million, which compares to $57 million of free cash f
componenttext:
Thanks, Wade.
I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed.
For the quarter, we had a cash use of $152 million, which compares to $57 million of free cash flow in the December quarter of last year. Page 5 of the web presentation provides the components of free cash flow. The decline in free cash flow versus the prior year was principally due to higher working capital utilization and lower operating income. Working capital was negatively impacted by the timing of film receivables from home entertainment and television.
Now moving on to our debt. It remains principally fixed rate, with an average cost at the end of the quarter of 4.6%. We ended the quarter with $12.6 billion of total debt and $327 million cash and cash equivalents. At the end of the quarter, our leverage ratio was 3.2x. We have $368 million remaining outstanding of our 6.25% senior notes which mature on April 30. We plan on paying these notes off.
Now let's turn to some of the factors impacting fiscal 2016. In terms of affiliate revenues, quarterly affiliate revenue will fluctuate according to the timing of transactions and the recognition of revenue related to certain distribution agreements which are tied to product availability. For the fiscal year 2016, we expect growth in affiliate revenues to be in the low, mid-single-digit range. For the full year, we expect that Media Networks programming expense growth rate will be in the mid-single digits. In terms of taxes, for 2016, we are forecasting a book tax rate of approximately 32.5%. We will refine this as we go through the year and get a better sense of the domestic-international profitability mix.
At Paramount, we are excited about the upcoming slate, including our summer tentpoles Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 2 and Star Trek 3. For fiscal 2016, we expect profits to be weighted to the back half of the year as the studio benefits from their summer releases. Looking ahead of the studio's production and development pipeline: Paramount has just wrapped production on Jack Reacher 2. This month, the studio is commencing production on 4 major films. Scarlett Johansson will star in Ghost in the Shell, which is in partnership with DreamWorks. Baywatch, starring Dwayne Johnson and Zac Efron; the newest chapter in Vin Diesel's action franchise, xXx 3, The Return of Xander Cage; and a romantic thriller set in World War II, which is directed by Robert Zemeckis and stars Brad Pitt and Marion Cotillard. In the spring, the studio starts production on Academy Award-winning filmmaker Alexander Payne's next movie called Downsizing, starring Matt Damon.
In summary, while last year we experienced broad ratings weaknesses, we took organizational and creative steps to address those challenges. The progress we began to see at the end of fiscal 2015 is continuing. In the December quarter, 6 of our top 10 networks saw a growth in ratings. In March quarter-to-date, we are seeing ratings growth for our overall portfolio of Media Networks. At Paramount, they have started the fiscal year with several successes at the box office, and we look forward to the summer tentpole releases. In terms of our international Media Networks, we are benefiting from our investment over the past several years and anticipate strong double-digit growth in profits this year. The acquisition of Channel 5 has been an unqualified success. And the continued launch of new networks in Europe, Latin America and Africa has enabled us to build and grow our scale in the most important developing and developed markets.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to your questions. Operator?

componenttextpreview: Well, look, Sumner and I have been in harmony in how we pursue our strategy going forward. Obviously, as we all know, the world is changing. Our specific industry is changing. We have taken a significant number of steps, which I outlined in my remarks, I
componenttext: Well, look, Sumner and I have been in harmony in how we pursue our strategy going forward. Obviously, as we all know, the world is changing. Our specific industry is changing. We have taken a significant number of steps, which I outlined in my remarks, I won't repeat it, to move into the future, to build the existing ecosystem, revitalize our brands, grow internationally, grow on multiple platforms. The Snapchat deal that we announced this morning is an indicator. You will see more deals to come. As I said in my remarks, I will leave no stone unturned. I never have, and I never will. And our objective is to build value. We are building value for the long term. We are building value with a view to getting our -- a better valuation of our stock in the short term, but we will not take actions that undermine that value. And we believe that, with consistency in leadership, consistency in purpose; driving our content around the world, across multiple platforms; finding new source of revenues in licensing, consumer products and other areas, we will get Viacom back to the growth that we all want to see.

componenttext: We're seeing strong demand in the scatter market, and strong pricing. We're seeing pricing in the scatter market over the last upfront in the neighborhood of 20%, so that bodes very well for the upcoming upfront. What bodes particularly well for us is the great progress that we're making across most of our networks, which I believe will turn into virtually all of our networks in short order. We are seeing a great appetite for our leading Viacom Vantage, Viacom Echo and Viacom Velocity products. We are determined to get back to ad growth. We've also looked at having a healthy environment for our marketing partners. As you know, we have taken down our ad load in several key time periods across several of our networks. And that, to some extent, might have suppressed some of the short-term advertising growth, but I think it is healthy for us and will lead to very healthy return to ad growth as we improve over the back half of the year and into next year.

As you know, in this year, we had ramped up to 11 major advertisers. I said in the last earnings call we expect that number to triple, thereby representing a large portion of our advertising revenues as we go into next year, as a result of the upfront discussions we're having. We're able to offer reach into other platforms like Snapchat, which we announced this morning. And we're also seeing some moves by Nielsen to improve its measurements. We're seeing some competition coming up with the comScore-Rentrak combination. So all of these together will move toward better capturing the actual reach that our networks have.

componenttext: Thank you, Alexia. Yes, as far as the ad market, again, we are looking at the general health of our networks. You're quite right. We're seeing improvement. We do have some work to do in our Comedy Central and MTV networks. MTV in particular will take a little more time because the new management's programming will be kicking in later, and that's going to be significant. It's still early in the quarter. We expect this quarter to be in the vicinity of where we're going to see some meaningful progress in the back half of the year, with our objective by the end of there to be poised for growth and sustainable, which is what we're looking for, sustainable growth in advertising revenues. And as far as the buyback is concerned, right now, we are focused on strengthening our operations. We're paying down debt, as Tom mentioned. We are not refinancing. We're paying off an upcoming maturity. We are committed to our investment-grade rating. And in due course, as we have availability within that framework, we will move forward at the appropriate time in the future to utilize the capacity that we have in our buyback program.

componenttext: Doug, on our leverage targets, look, we want to be solidly investment grade as a company. As you remember, back in 2008, '09, we delevered the balance sheet relatively quickly. That's due to the company's very strong free cash flow generation capability. We think we can get down into the ranges that leverage some of the -- or rating agencies are looking for companies like ours to operate within. And we've got a stated target of 2.75 to 3.0. And we're going to operate within that metric and perhaps at the lower end of that metric, and then we'll look from there where the operations are and the opportunity is to buy back shares at that point.

componenttext: I've got two. The first one, for Philippe. I just wanted to follow up on what you said at the end of your prepared remarks. Like, what was it trait-wise that the board looked in you and said that was why, that was the right decision for Viacom? componenttext: Rich, I'll -- the -- first of all, as far as the performance of Viacom, let me just challenge what you indicated. Viacom's performance was at the top. In fact, we had 5 consecutive years of being -- significantly beating the S&P in our stock performance. Clearly, we have fallen back a lot in the last 2 and especially last year. Some of the decline was accentuated in the recent past by a lot of noise that existed around us. And I think some people who have been buying the stock in that period are -- had the foresight to see through the noise. And I think we have outlined the steps we are taking, the forward-looking steps we are taking; and the progress we are making in several aspects of our operations. And then I leave it to the board. I'm gratified that the board overwhelmingly supported me for the position. They know me. They know what our plans are, strategic plans. They know what -- our operational plans. They endorse them. They have confidence in them. And I will repay back that confidence by producing the results without shirking our obligation to make the changes that are necessary to make Viacom the leading content company of the future. That is our objective. As far as your question relating to Comcast, yes, they have violated our agreements, and we are going to not sit back. We have not filed a lawsuit against Comcast, but we will preserve our rights as we go forward.

componenttext: Thank you, Vasily. Look, we are -- let me take that in 2 parts. As far as Comedy Central goes, clearly, we have great creative output there that's resonating with our audiences. We have a number of returning series that are coming on-stream to add to what's already there, so I think we have a healthy pipeline at Comedy Central. And I think, over time, that will take care of itself. And it's very attractive programming that reaches young audiences and attractive to advertisers. As far as MTV goes, MTV is in more of a rebuilding mode. We have a new Head of MTV that started just a very few months ago who has revamped his team; has, as I mentioned in my remarks, greenlit new series. We need -- needed and need more programming on MTV. That will start kicking in over time. We are accelerating the airing of the shows that are already in production so that we can fill the schedule better. We're going to add new shows, and that will just build on itself over the next several months and quarters. So it's a little bit of a different exercise there, but I think the energy that's being applied to it, the new enthusiasm for it, the reaching out to more programming sources and more relevant programming sources is very encouraging. And I feel very good about the future there.

componenttext: We don't break out that kind of information we have in our history. Obviously, we know it's a different level of materiality for Viacom than it is for a Lionsgate.
