componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for taking the time to join us for our December Quarter Earnings Call. 
Listening from Los Angeles is our Chairman Emeritus, Sumner Redstone. And joining us in New York are Philippe Dauman, our Executive Chairman, President and CEO; Tom Dooley, our Chief Operating Officer; and Wade Davis, our Chief Financial Officer.
Please note that, in addition to our press release, we have slides and trending schedules containing supplemental information available on our website. I want to refer you to Page #2 in the web presentation and remind you that certain statements made on this call are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in more detail in our filings with the SEC. Today's remarks will focus on adjusted results. Reconciliations for non-GAAP financial information discussed on this call can be found in our earnings release or on our website.
And now I'll turn the call over to Philippe.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's first quarter results.First, I want to thank my colleague, mentor and friend Sumner, who is listening on the phone, for his vision, his guidance and his inspiration
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's first quarter results.
First, I want to thank my colleague, mentor and friend Sumner, who is listening on the phone, for his vision, his guidance and his inspiration, all of which will continue to energize us with Sumner as our Chairman Emeritus. I am honored to be the new Executive Chairman of Viacom, and I will do my utmost to continue to drive Viacom's operations forward and restore our stock to its proper valuation, but more on that later in my remarks.
Now let's take a quick look at the numbers. In the first quarter, revenues declined 6% to $3.15 billion. Adjusted operating income was $839 million, and adjusted net earnings from continuing operations were $470 million. Adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations declined 9% to $1.18 per diluted share.
2015 was a challenging year for Viacom as it was for many in the industry. However, it was a watershed year in which we took many important steps to position Viacom for the future. We reorganized and refocused our organization, increasing both our Media Networks and Filmed Entertainment production pipelines. We also stepped up our investment in data measurement and marketing expertise and fueled our growth in the most attractive overseas markets. And we did all of this while delivering record earnings per share in 2015 and the highest Media Networks revenue in our history. As we turn the corner into 2016, the hard work and investment is bearing fruit. Let me give you a few of the highlights.
We have dynamic new leadership in our business units and several of our major networks, including MTV and VH1. Viacom's creative culture is stronger than ever. Our focus on original programming and rapid deployment is paying off. Existing hits such as Lip Sync Battle, PAW Patrol, Love & Hip Hop; and exciting new programming like Game Shakers, Younger, Teachers and I Love Kellie Pickler are continuing to attract valuable and devoted audiences. In fact, Viacom had 7 of the top 20 cable series in the quarter. Most major networks have seen year-over-year ratings improvement, and that ratings strength is driving advertising improvement. There'll be more to come as the changes underway at Comedy Central and MTV kick in and the ad market continues to strengthen.
An enhanced distribution ecosystem is coming together with strong upside for content providers. We are experimenting and reaping the benefits of increased consumer choice. Our international business is a strong performer with great upside but remains underappreciated. We are expanding distribution, creating differentiated and popular content, building on Channel 5's substantial successes, launching the high-margin Paramount Channel to even more territories and building our success in India's high-growth market. And Paramount is into its rebuilding process with the movie pipeline improving and TV operations off to a strong start. Already, we've seen solid critical response in box office performance from the first quarter releases, and there is much more to come throughout the year.
Turning to the Media Networks results. Revenues declined 3% to $2.57 billion in the quarter, including a 1% adverse impact of foreign exchange. 
Before we move on to discuss our advertising results in detail, I'd like to spend a moment to discuss the wide-ranging and innovative agreement with Snapchat that we announced this morning. The deal is important for a number of reasons, not the least of which is that it is indicative of the flexible and innovative approach we are taking to grow our digital and mobile expertise rapidly and at a global scale. As part of the deal, we will bring 2 new high-profile channels to Snapchat Discover: a Comedy Central international channel and an MTV channel in the U.S. These, on top of our other successful discovery channels, make us one of the largest publishers on Snapchat Discover. Importantly, Viacom will also become the external ad sales representative for Snapchat's advertising inventory, giving us the chance to offer even more value to our clients. In addition, validating the continuing cultural influence of our programming, Snapchat will increase the number of Live Stories it publishes tied to Viacom's tentpole events, such as the VMAs, the EMAs, the BET awards and others. Snapchat's immersive and extremely popular short-form video platform aligns perfectly with our leadership in both premium long- and short-form storytelling for these same audiences.
This deal between Viacom and Snapchat is a major step forward in the evolution of the marketplace, made possible by our shared focus on young audiences and Viacom's content expertise, proprietary targeting, custom marketing solutions, industry-leading sales force, and our global strength. It's a great partnership for both companies and is indicative of more innovation to come.
Looking back on the quarter. Domestic ad sales declined 4% in the quarter, a substantial sequential improvement from the prior quarter. Continued ratings gains based on the content investment we made over the last few years across our channel groups are driving this positive momentum. Most of our networks are performing well and are making meaningful contributions as audience levels build. Excluding the performance of Comedy Central and MTV, our domestic television ad sales growth was solidly positive. Once ratings at MTV and Comedy Central turn around, and that work is well underway, the rebound will be even more clear. And the rebound will be fueled by Viacom's continuing leadership in delivery of the most progressive and innovative solutions in the marketplace.
We recently announced an update to our proprietary Echo platform, which measures the effectiveness of custom-creative social marketing campaigns. We'll go to the upfront with expanded offerings in Vantage and clients are already embracing the new Velocity content network, harnessing Velocity's creative and production resources to create data-driven, branded content programs distributed across social platforms for advertising partners.
Domestic affiliate revenues are substantially flat in the quarter with positive organic growth offset by the timing of content available to certain digital distributors. Absent that impact, domestic affiliate revenues grew in the low mid-single digits. With the majority of our distribution agreements locked in to long-term deals, we had no large renewals in the quarter. However, we continue to work closely with these partners to develop new avenues for viewers to enjoy Viacom programming. To-date, our authenticated sites and apps reach 75% of the subscriber universe. And in the quarter, we launched robust Apple TV apps for Nickelodeon, Nick Jr., Comedy Central and MTV; and apps on Roku for MTV and Nick Jr. Viacom is currently in negotiations to extend our distribution agreement with DISH, with whom we have a long and productive relationship. We have entered into a short-term extension with them as we hammer out the details of a long-term renewal. There may be short-term hiccups along the way, but we firmly believe that we will ultimately reach an agreement that will be productive for both sides. 
It has been a strong quarter for many of our individual networks, each of which has become more flexible, more aggressive and more entrepreneurial. There is greater sharing of strategies and best practices across the house, which enhances our ability to make the most of the unprecedented amount of high-quality original programming we are rolling out.
Original programming is key to reducing viewer fatigue, provides greater opportunities for advertiser integration, brings value in secondary markets and reinforces our network's cultural impact at the virtual and the real-world watercooler. There's no better example of this than Nickelodeon, our biggest brand. In the first quarter, Nick's ratings improved over the prior year, and in the current quarter, we are looking at greater gains. Nickelodeon is the 2 to 11 leader in total day ratings and has beaten its nearest competitor for 26 weeks straight in this demo. In fact, Nick's lead over the competition continued to widen in the quarter with Nickelodeon 30% ahead of Disney and 78% ahead of Cartoon Network. We had the #1 and #2 kids series in the quarter. Nick's newest preschool hit, Blaze and the Monster Machines, ranked #1 across TV with kids 2 to 5, posting gains of 47% from a year ago. PAW Patrol continued its strength in second place.
This year, Nick animation celebrates its 25th anniversary, and its creative culture has never been more vibrant. In the quarter, Nick owned the top 3 animated shows on TV with kids 2 to 11: ALVINNN!!!, SpongeBob SquarePants and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. A new season of Turtles kicked off last month, and we'll have new episodes from SpongeBob, The Fairly Odd Parents, ALVINNN!!!, Harvey Beaks, Sanjay & Craig, Pig Goat Banana Cricket, Rabbids and Miraculous throughout the quarter. And next month, Blake Shelton will be hosting the Kids' Choice Awards, Nickelodeon's most important tentpole.
VH1 is another turnaround story that we're extremely excited about. Under new leadership, the network has reversed earlier ratings declines, and that positive momentum is accelerating faster than at any other Viacom brand. VH1's first quarter prime-time ratings in the 18 to 49 demo were up 5%, and in the quarter, ratings were up a stunning 40%. VH1 is now the #1 prime-time cable network on Mondays among adults 18 to 49 and a top 10 cable network overall in that demo. Driven by the Love & Hip Hop and Black Ink Crew franchises, VH1 had 4 of the top 20 original cable series in the first quarter. And the network is expanding on this success, increasing its output of original programming through an additional night per week.
TV Land C3 ratings were also up in the quarter as smart acquisitions drove sequentially higher viewership each month. As we move to the current quarter, TV Land's high-quality original programming is already hitting, with the season 2 premiere of Younger driving 78% higher ratings than the season 1 series premier. In addition, Teachers, the critically acclaimed new comedy, has gotten off to a solid start. As we move through the quarter, the network will debut the single-cam comedy Lopez, starring George Lopez; and the final season of The Soul Man, featuring Cedric the Entertainer and Niecy Nash.
BET also benefited from the steady investment in distinctive content. It continues to build momentum and exhibits strong ratings growth. The network has reversed significant challenges in 2015, culminating in double-digit ratings growth in the first quarter. BET is now the #16 ad-supported cable network among adults 18 to 49, up from #20 a year ago. And it's the only network among the top 20 to post double-digit ratings gains over last year. BET remains the #1 cable TV network among African-Americans. 
We're proud of what the BET team has done and how quickly they are reaping the rewards of the targeted investments in programming we've made. The best is yet to come at BET, and we're looking forward to continued growth as the network continues its evolution.
Spike had a solid first quarter with premieres of Ink Master drawing higher ratings and the Bar Rescue franchise showing continued strength and growth. Spike teased its second season of Lip Sync Battle with its first holiday special, which delivered almost 2 million viewers and was the #1 entertainment show on cable with all viewers 18 to 49 as well as women 18 to 49. Joseph Gordon-Levitt's performance of Rhythm Nation has become a pop culture sensation now with 10 million views on YouTube and growing. Moving to the current quarter, the official season 2 premiere of Lip Sync Battle shattered ratings and digital records for the network. The 1-hour special drew 4.7 million viewers, making it the most-watched original series episode in Spike history. The season 2 debut is the #1 ranked show in all of television in the time slot with adults 18 to 49 and adults 18 to 34 as well as women 18 to 49 and women 18 to 34. The season 2 premiere has been viewed over 55 million times on various digital platforms. 
To-date, Lip Sync Battle content overall secured 0.5 billion views across all platforms. Lip Sync Battle is without a doubt a global phenomenon. The U.S. version of the program can now be seen in 120 countries and territories worldwide. The format is also under license in more than 30 territories, most recently debuting in China where 30 million people viewed the program online in its first weekend. In addition, we have already launched the format on Channel 5 in the U.K, to great success, where it is averaging a 22% share among viewers 16 to 34.
Comedy Central remains a force with men 18 to 34 with 4 of the top 25 cable entertainment series in the quarter. South Park showed continued strength and ranked #2 in that demo. And The Daily Show with Trevor Noah was the most-watched late-night talk show for this valuable audience as well as with adults 18 to 24. The story of The Daily Show is strong with 3 consecutive months of growth with total viewers and video consumption, including a robust 3 million full-episode starts each week across digital platforms. Trevor Noah has proven to be a star, and he will continue to build on his strong start, especially with valuable young audiences across multiple platforms. Historically, The Daily Show sees double-digit increases in a presidential election year, so we believe even better results are ahead.
Some soft spots in our schedule and ongoing consumption shifts to under-measured platforms resulted in challenging ratings overall, but I have great confidence Comedy Central will overcome these issues. The recent renewals of Inside Amy Schumer and Broad City are continuing evidence that the network is on solid creative footing and remains the first choice for today's hottest comedy talent. We're already seeing a rebound. Ratings in the second half of the quarter began to improve, led by a new season of Workaholics and the series premiere of Idiotsitter. In addition, tonight, Comedy Central will kick off a new season of Tosh.0; and premiere Not Safe With Nikki Glaser, a new, very naughty and very funny series from a popular comedian.
Despite several bright spots, MTV experienced a difficult first quarter overall. Scripted originals still ranked at the top of their time periods, but ratings were lower than expected. As MTV moved into the second quarter, 2 of the network's best-performing franchises, Teen Mom and Teen Wolf, returned to strong LIVE+3 ratings. And the premiere of the epic fantasy series The Shannara Chronicles drew 7.5 million viewers across all telecasts. MTV's development process didn't adapt quickly enough to the shifting preferences of its audiences. We're fixing that by accelerating its development pipeline and returning its best series in faster cycles. The network's new management is deep in a turnaround plan and has already greenlit several new series with 4 slated for fiscal 2016. I have complete confidence that MTV is headed in the right direction.
Outside the U.S., our footprint continues to grow with launches of TeenNick in Italy, BET in France, and Comedy Central in the Czech Republic and Norway. In addition, Viacom International Media Networks will be launching the Paramount Channel in Italy at the end of the month. Paramount Channel continues to be a good, strategic business for us. It is already profitable and allows us to further monetize owned content at minimal incremental cost.
As you know, India has been an area of great focus and thoughtful investment for Viacom. It is the world's leading growth market in a country where we are growing our revenues and growing our share. In the mass entertainment category, Colors has now established itself as a top-ranked urban channel in India. MTV is #1 in the youth genre. Nickelodeon is #1 with kids, and VH1 is the #1 English entertainment network. Our India channels are quickly building large, dedicated audiences, and there are very exciting opportunities to come.
Paramount closed the first quarter with 2 December releases that have exceeded expectations. Daddy's Home, starting Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg, has already earned more than $210 million at the global box office. And the 5-time Academy Award-nominated The Big Short continues to win accolades, including top honors at the Producers Guild Awards. It's a good start to an important year for Paramount, one where we will once again make full use of our exceptional infrastructure and talent. Coming up this weekend, Paramount will be releasing the highly anticipated Zoolander 2, which has been generating great buzz for months. Later in the quarter, we'll have Whiskey Tango Foxtrot featuring Tina Fey; and producer J.J. Abrams' 10 Cloverfield Lane. Looking through the end of 2016, Paramount will be releasing Star Trek Beyond, also from producer J.J. Abrams; Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows from producer Michael Bay; and a reimagining of the classic Ben-Hur. And next fiscal year, Paramount's full slate will include an all-new Jack Reacher starring Tom Cruise, Paramount Animation's Monster Trucks, and an epic thriller directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring Brad Pitt.
Paramount Television's quarter also started out strong with a live production of Grease on FOX. The telecast was a hit with critics and audiences and delivered more than 14 million LIVE+3 viewers in the U.S.
Paramount is a very valuable and significantly undervalued part of Viacom. Its library of hit films generates significant recurring income year after year. It has been, from a historical standpoint, in a brief income slump due in part to a recent low number of theatrical releases, which reduces the positive waterfall impact of prior year film releases. This will change now that we are back on track to release approximately 15 high-quality releases a year, including numerous tentpoles. 
At the same time, what is now a low-cost start-up television production operation will ramp up to profitability over the next few years. Once we get through this rebuilding process and related investment, we expect Paramount to pump out significant operating income and free cash flow in the years to come. At the same time, its content will provide the fuel for EPIX in the U.S., a growing number of Paramount channels outside of the U.S.; and will serve as an important source of television content for Media Networks, including Nickelodeon, Spike and MTV.
In conclusion, I want to address the speculation about Viacom and our future. Our outlook and the facts have been distorted and obscured by the naysayers, self-interested critics and publicity seekers. We will not be distracted or deterred as we build for the bright future ahead of us. As Executive Chairman and CEO, I will continue to work tirelessly to secure that future and will leave no stone unturned either tactically or strategically. Sumner and I have a more than 30-year history side-by-side building his media empire. He and the board of Viacom, believing in my abilities and my character, have entrusted me with weighty responsibilities, none of which are inconsistent or incompatible. My singular objective is to protect and build value for all of Viacom shareholders and, in doing so, for all the beneficiaries of Sumner's trust not only include the descendants of his daughter but also those of her brother. And finally, let me be absolutely clear: I could not be more focused on getting Viacom's stock price back to the much higher level it enjoyed under my leadership just a short time ago. No one should doubt my resolve or the resolve of our entire management team in making that happen. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Wade.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our December quarter are available on our website. Now let's take a look at our segment results.
componenttext:
Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our December quarter are available on our website. Now let's take a look at our segment results.
At our Media Networks segment, revenues in the quarter were down 3% compared with the prior year. Domestic revenues decreased 3%, and international revenues declined 4%. Excluding a 7% unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues were up 3%, reflecting growth in advertising and affiliate revenues. Page 9 of our web deck provides a breakdown of our Media Networks revenue performance.
In terms of advertising, worldwide revenues declined 3% in the quarter. Domestic revenues were down 4%, and international revenues were down 2%. Excluding foreign exchange, which had an 8 percentage point unfavorable impact, international advertising grew 6% driven by growth in Europe. In terms of affiliate revenues, worldwide revenues were down 1%. Domestic revenues were substantially flat in the quarter while international revenues declined 6%. Domestic affiliate revenues were unfavorably impacted by the timing of product available under certain distribution agreements. Foreign exchange had a 9 percentage point unfavorable impact on international affiliate revenue growth. Ancillary revenues were down 19%, driven by lower consumer products revenue, reflecting comparisons to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles merchandise sale in the December quarter of last year as well as the decline in television syndication revenue.
Expenses decreased 3% in the quarter. Within operating expenses, programming expenses were down 3%, while distribution and other expenses decreased 4%. SG&A expense decreased 2% in the quarter. The decreases in programming and SG&A costs were principally due to the savings from our strategic realignment last year.
Media Networks' adjusted operating income was down 4% for the quarter, and the adjusted operating income margin was 41%. The decline in operating income was driven by the revenue decline of 3% partially offset by the 3% decline in expenses.
Moving to Filmed Entertainment. Revenues were down 15% in the quarter principally due to decreases in theatrical and home entertainment revenues partially offset by an increase in license fees. Foreign exchange had a 3 percentage point unfavorable impact on Filmed Entertainment revenue growth. Page 12 of the web presentation provides a breakdown of Filmed Entertainment revenues.
Theatrical revenues declined 44%. The decline in revenues was due to lower carryover revenues given the difficult comparison to the strong performance of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles in the December quarter of last year as well as lower revenues from our current-quarter releases. Of our more significant releases, The Big Short and Daddy's Home, were both released in December of this year compared to Interstellar, which was released earlier in last year's December quarter. Home entertainment revenues declined 24% reflecting lower carryover revenues due to comparisons to Transformers: Age of Extinction in the December quarter of last year. 
Revenue from license fees increased 25% primarily driven by the licensing of certain titles in subscription video-on-demand and television. Filmed Entertainment generated an adjusted operating loss of $146 million in the quarter as compared to a loss of $60 million last year. The decrease in operating results reflects the timing and mix of current-quarter releases as well as lower contributions from prior-period releases.
Now moving beyond the segment results. The other items line reflects a gain of $2 million versus 18 -- an $18 million loss in the December quarter of last year. Last year's loss was principally due to foreign exchange. In terms of taxes, the adjusted effective tax rate was 32.8%, reflecting a 50 basis point increase as compared to the prior year.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed.For the quarter, we had a cash use of $152 million, which compares to $57 million of free cash fl
componenttext:
Thanks, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed.
For the quarter, we had a cash use of $152 million, which compares to $57 million of free cash flow in the December quarter of last year. Page 5 of the web presentation provides the components of free cash flow. The decline in free cash flow versus the prior year was principally due to higher working capital utilizations and lower operating income. Working capital was negatively impacted by the timing of film receivables from home entertainment and television.
Now moving on to our debt. It remains principally fixed rate with an average cost at the end of the quarter of 4.6%. We ended the quarter with $12.6 billion of total debt and $327 million of cash and cash equivalents. At the end of the quarter, our leverage ratio was 3.2x. We have $368 million remaining outstanding of our 6.25% senior notes, which mature on April 30. We plan on paying these notes off.
Now let's turn to some of the factors impacting fiscal 2016. In terms of affiliate revenues, quarterly affiliate revenue will fluctuate according to the timing of transactions and the recognition of revenue related to certain distribution agreements which are tied to product availability. For the fiscal year 2016, we expect growth in affiliate revenues to be in the low mid-single-digit range. For the full year, we expect that Media Networks programming expense growth rate will be in the mid-single digits. In terms of taxes, for 2016, we are forecasting a book tax rate of approximately 32.5%. We will refine this as we go through the year and get a better sense of the domestic-international profitability mix.
At Paramount, we are excited about the upcoming slate, including our summer tentpoles Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 2 and Star Trek 3. For fiscal 2016, we expect profits to be weighted to the back half of the year as the studio benefits from their summer releases. Looking ahead at the studio's production and development pipeline. Paramount has just wrapped production on Jack Reacher 2. This month, the studio is commencing production on 4 major films. Scarlett Johansson will star in Ghost in the Shell, which is in partnership with DreamWorks. Baywatch, starring Dwayne Johnson and Zac Efron; the newest chapter in Vin Diesel's action franchise, xXx 3: The Return of Xander Cage; and the romantic thriller set in World War II, which is directed by Robert Zemeckis and stars Brad Pitt and Marion Cotillard. In the spring, the studio starts production on Academy Award-winning filmmaker Alexander Payne's next movie called Downsizing, starring Matt Damon.
In summary, while last year we experienced broad ratings weaknesses, we took organizational and creative steps to address those challenges. The progress we began to see at the end of fiscal 2015 is continuing. In the December quarter, 6 of our top 10 networks saw a growth in ratings. In March quarter-to-date, we are seeing ratings growth for our overall portfolio of Media Networks. At Paramount, they have started the fiscal year with several successes at the box office, and we look forward to the summer tentpole releases. In terms of our international Media Networks, we are benefiting from our investment over the past several years and anticipate strong double-digit growth in profits this year. The acquisition of Channel 5 has been an unqualified success. And the continued launch of new networks in Europe, Latin America and Africa has enabled us to build and grow our scale in the most important developing and developed markets.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to your questions. Operator?

componenttext: Well, look, Sumner and I have been in harmony in how we pursue our strategy going forward. Obviously, as we all know, the world is changing. Our specific industry is changing. We have taken a significant number of steps, which I outlined in my remarks -- I won't repeat it, to move into the future, to build the existing ecosystem, revitalize our brands, grow internationally, grow on multiple platforms. The Snapchat deal that we announced this morning is an indicator. You will see more deals to come. As I said in my remarks, I will leave no stone unturned. I never have and I never will. And our objective is to build value. We are building value for the long term. We are building value with a view to getting our -- a better valuation of our stock in the short term, but we will not take actions that undermine that value. And we believe that with consistency in leadership; consistency in purpose; driving our content around the world across multiple platforms; finding new source of revenues in licensing, consumer products and other areas; we will get Viacom back to the growth that we all want to see.

componenttext: Rich, I'll -- the -- first of all, as far as the performance of Viacom, let me just challenge what you indicated. Viacom's performance was at the top. I'm gratified that the board overwhelmingly supported me for the position. They know me. They know what our plans are, strategic plans. They know what -- our operational plans. They endorse them. And I will repay back that confidence by producing the results without shirking our obligation to make the changes that are necessary to make Viacom the leading content company of the future. That is our objective. As far as your question relating to Comcast, yes, they have violated our agreements, and we are going to not sit back. If you look at the independent kind of smaller film studios that are publicly traded, they'll probably trade at kind of premium multiples, I think, in part based on people's view of the value of the library. And you get some good disclosures there from people like Lionsgate, run by a former colleague of yours, which talks about $500 million of library revenues, nearly $200 million of library EBITDA. Could you guys give us a sense of the library revenues and cash flow at Paramount? Presumably, it's bigger. And could you give us any way to kind of get a handle on the value and the cash flows from that?

componenttext: We don't break out that kind of information. We haven't in our history. Obviously, we know it's a different level of materiality for Viacom than it is for a Lionsgate. I think it's clear that there is a lot of value there. And as I've indicated before, we've also used a library to build assets, in our case, using our channel distribution capability. I mentioned EPIX in the U.S. And the Paramount channels are really adding scale and new demographic reach for us in many, many countries around the world and still growing. The ratings performance is really strong. And it is really helping to accelerate the growth of our international business, which is a really underappreciated story as I mentioned. We are building very significant value there and if you even break down components of our international business, notably India, and see the important value creation that's taking place. So Paramount has -- as other studios have at various stages, has had a little slump in output on current production. I have -- but I have confidence in the team there. I like what I see in terms of development. And that will improve the overall results and, of course, add to the impressive library that Paramount has, as you mentioned.

componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for taking the time to join as for our March quarter earnings call. Joining me for today's discussion are Philippe Dauman, our Executive Chairman, President and CEO; Tom Dooley, our Chief Operating Officer; and Wade Davis, our Chief Financial Officer.
Please note that, in addition to our press release, we have slides and trending schedules containing supplemental information available on our website.
I want to refer you to Page #2 in the web presentation and remind you that certain statements made on this call are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in more detail in our filings with the SEC.
Today's remarks will focus on adjusted results. Reconciliations for non-GAAP financial information discussed on this call can be found in our earnings release or on our website.
And now, I'll turn the call over to Philippe.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's results for 2016 second quarter. As we move forward, we have several notable areas of strength, including ratings improvement in key network, solid visibility on long-ter
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's results for 2016 second quarter. As we move forward, we have several notable areas of strength, including ratings improvement in key network, solid visibility on long-term affiliate revenue growth, increasing value generated from the growing use of technology and data and continued growth in our international business. We made solid progress in the quarter driving significant change across our brands to increase the value of our content and better position us for the future. 
There are 4 major strategic objectives driving change and future growth at Viacom. First and foremost, we continued to make substantial investments in content, specifically original content, a long-term imperative that is generating clear result and building long-term value. This includes steadily escalating content investments in television and film as well as short-form mobile content. Second, we are upgrading and expanding our already substantial data capabilities to deliver more accurate metrics for advertisers and greater monetization potential. We are out in the lead in this area and are beginning to reap the benefit, which will accelerate as we go forward. Third, we are maximizing our opportunities for revenue growth with traditional distributors, while moving forward with new forms of distribution. Our content ownership and the popularity of our content on new platforms and social media are providing new options as the ecosystem evolves. And fourth, we continue to look at strategic options to enhance our competitive position and unlock the value of our businesses. Our exploration of the strategic minority investor in Paramount is an excellent example as is our continued international expansion. 
Looking at the numbers, in the second quarter, revenues declined 3% to $3 billion. Adjusted operating income was $586 million and adjusted net earnings from continuing operations were $303 million. Adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations declined to $0.76 per diluted share. 
Turning to Media Networks. Revenues declined 3% to $2.38 billion in the quarter. Ad sales revenues were down 5% in the U.S. While it is early in the quarter, we hope to improve the rate of change in ad sales revenue even as we reduce unit load at several of our network, which bodes well for brand health and future financial performance. 
This year, we expect a strong upfront, a tripling of Viacom vantage clients and additional interest in kids, where Viacom has some of its greatest strength. The movie studios are coming to this upfront with the increased number of kids and family-oriented theatrical releases and as the dominant kids network, this is very positive for Nickelodeon. 
In addition, we have recently launched Viacom Vantage studio audition, the first data-driven ad product specifically for the studio category where we see significant opportunities for overall growth. Domestic affiliate revenues in the current quarter decreased 2%, impacted as we had previously discussed at the rate realignment with a major distributor and slight declines in distribution in line with industry trends. SVOD revenues are expected to be more significant in the second half of our fiscal year. 
Based on the long-term deals we've recently closed, we expect to grow affiliate revenues with traditional distributors and overall at mid-single digit rates in 2017 when the rate realignment will be behind us and beyond. 
Our recent renewal with DISH on favorable terms was an important moment for Viacom. In the past year, we have successfully renewed distribution deals with several major distributors representing over 44 million subscribers. We now have long-term deals in place with all of the major distributors and an extended runway for steady affiliate revenue growth. 
We have a real opportunity to build on that momentum. Our networks are highly valued by our cable, satellite and telco partners because they drive substantial live and video-on-demand viewership. In fact, the reach of our networks is vastly underappreciated. We continue to own the largest share of viewership in multiple key demographics on the highly monetizable cable-television platform. Viacom networks combined represents the largest share of cable viewing of any cable family for all viewers 2 plus according to Nielsen. And we gained more share compared to a year ago than any other family of cable networks among viewers 2 to 49, where we have 21% of viewership. We also have the largest share of viewers 18 to 34, also 21% and 18 to 49 at over 17%. 
The significance of this share shift will become even more evident as new, more robust measurement tools take hold in the market. In addition, our networks and the demos they attract are much desired for OTT streaming service is from new entrants in the industry as well as of those developed by the traditional distributors such as Swing. 
While cable penetration continues to decline across the industry, the penetration of connected devices is growing at a double-digit clip. In fact, 34% of broadband households subscribed to 2 or more paid Internet video services. The Viacom network portfolio is the leader in the U.S. among broadband-only homes and drive significant viewership on long-form platforms like Amazon, Hulu and Roku, as well as on short-form platforms like YouTube and Snapchat. Viacom's strong position as a valued content provider in both traditional cable and the fast-growing broadband and the mobile universe will continue to work in our favor as we lead the content providers into this new world. 
It gives us great confidence that our brands connection with valuable audiences are as strong as ever. We will maintain our focus on improving traditional ratings and also work to increase monetization in broadband power distribution by collaborating with our partners on subscription models and advertising features that will make these platforms more economically attractive. 
One of the ways we're meeting these challenges is by continuing to expand our data and add technology capability, exemplified by today's announcement with Roku. Among connected device owners, Roku Holmes have the highest reach, average days used and hours used per day. In fact, Roku usage is greater than Xbox, Chrome Cast and Apple TV combined and that lead is accelerating. This first-of-its-kind partnership will allow us to leverage, aggregate data from Roku, enabling sophisticated ad targeting at an unprecedented scale in the TV environment. Through this partnership, we can offer better, more targeted ad product. We also have a financial investment in Roku. 
Combined with partnerships with comScore, TiVo, Symphony, Snapchat and several others, a continuing relationship with Nielsen and our expanding internal expertise, we're building a platform that's second to none. There is no question that Internet delivery is here to stay, and we continue to grow quickly through new and bigger OTT and SVOD services as well as an improving TV Everywhere experience. 
Now turning to a brief update on our Media Networks. We are rejuvenating and repositioning several of our network and seeing positive results. Viacom had 8 of the top 30 ad-supported cable networks in the 2-plus demo and 9 of the top 30 in the 18 to 49 demo, 1 more than last year in each. We also had the highest number of top 20 cable series among core demos. 
Nickelodeon continues its leading performance, taking the #1 spot in 2 to 11 for 37 consecutive weeks and pulling away from its competitors on a total day and head-to-head basis. Blaze and the Monster Machines was the #1 program across all television with young kids for the second consecutive quarter. 
Among kids 2 to 11, Nickelodeon on the top 2 animated shows, SpongeBob SquarePants and ALVINNN!!! and 4 of the top 5 programs throughout the quarter. On the consumer product side, Pop Patrol is the #1 preschool property with every mass retailer. The property is a success in nearly every license product category, including preschool toys, where it's #1, apparel, home goods and accessories. 
VH1 rating were the best in 6 years with strong double-digit gains across the board. At Spike, Lip Sync Battle remains the most-watched original series in the channels history, and Season 2 continues to deliver a big and a broad audience. It's also a global hit now in more than 120 countries. 
Bellator, which Spike acquired in 2011, is another global success story. Currently the fastest-growing combat sports franchise worldwide, Bellator is averaging 1.2 million viewers this year, a 45% increase over 2015. Bellator held its first European event in Torino, Italy this month with 2 additional international events planned this year, the first in London and airing on Viacom's Channel 5 and the second in Israel. We expect Bellator to grow into a significant Viacom asset in its own right. 
At MTV, overall ratings remain soft but MTV's programming continues to capture substantial audience share with 5 of the top 25 programs on cable among viewers 12 to 34. And the new overall and programming leadership, MTV is committed to bringing more live music and music-inspired programming into the network. Last week, MTV put on a reimagined upfront event that was very warmly received by the ad community. The upcoming slate features 14 new series and specials fueled by top-tier producing talent like Mark Barnett and including Wonderland, the network's first weekly live music performance series in nearly 20 years that debuts this fall. 
At Comedy Central, changing viewing patterns continue to impact ratings but declines narrowed significantly versus the prior quarter. Comedy Central continues to develop hit new programming, including this quarter's Not Safe With Nikki Glaser and has returning popular multiplatform shows, such as Inside Amy Schumer, Broad City, Touch.0 and Another Period. The turnaround of MTV and Comedy Central will be a driver of our advertising revenue recovery as we head into our next fiscal year. 
Viacom's international Media Networks performance continues to be strong with even more growth on the horizon. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange, advertising revenues increased 6% in the quarter and affiliate revenues rose 11% in the quarter. This is an important and underappreciated part of our portfolio that has grown significantly and now includes the Paramount Channel, Channel 5, Viacom 18, Spike, Comedy as well as even better, more localized MTV and Nickelodeon networks. Ratings are strong in our international brands particularly MTV. 
In India, Viacom and our JV partner have 16 networks and a country-leading position. We are showing strong growth in regional market and have recently launched [ph], on advertising supported VOD platform that will have Colors, MTV and Nick content as well as original long- and short-form content. 
In the U.K., our brands continue to show solid growth. Channel 5 reached its highest share ever in the 16 to 34 demo in the quarter and MTV, Nick and Comedy all posted double-digit share increases. Nickelodeon remains the #1 kids channel group in pay-television. 
International markets also give us a valuable opportunity to experiment with new digital platforms and monetization strategy. For example, Play Plex, a flexible app-based distribution platform for all of Viacom's global brands can help our pay-TV operator partners create a great TV Everywhere experience for consumers or be distributed as an over-the-top service. We are particularly excited about Play Plex as an authenticated or direct-to-consumer mobile product in markets without cable and pay-TV infrastructure. 
RMR results were disappointing this quarter, largely due to 2 titles that perform below expectations. We look forward to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles in the current quarter and the Start Trek Beyond, Ben-Hur, Jack Reacher tool, Rings in several other promising titles later in the year. 
Paramount Television continues to make rapid progress with 15 shows ordered to production and an additional 10 set up at networks, including Maniac, a comedy starting Emma Stone and Jonah Hill for Netflix. 
Turning to EPIX. We are looking forward to the introduction of its first 2 original scripted series in default, including Paramount's Berlin Station. EPIX has the youngest audience of all of the major premium services and was the fastest-growing premium network in the U.S., growing more than 35% year-over-year in 2015. 
The process of identifying a strategic minority investor in Paramount is continuing and on track to securing agreement by the end of June. The strategic and evaluation possibilities are compelling. Like the entire media industry, the motion picture business is evolving. A strong strategic partner for Paramount, particularly one that provides international and/or technological cloud and expertise will provide important benefits to both Paramount and Viacom. 
In summary, we are creating more and more original programming under revitalized network leadership and that is bearing fruit, both in the U.S. and abroad. We have secured renewals with all of our major U.S. distribution affiliates. We are entering to partnerships with a number of new market entrants, including Snapchat, Roku, comScore and more. Our international expansion will provide opportunities to drive significant value and growth for Viacom for the foreseeable future. And Paramount is poised for renewed success, driven by full slate and a vibrant television business. Our entire management team is completely focused on putting the building blocks for growth in place this year. We have a smart strategy and are investing in our properties in the U.S. and around the world, setting us up to become a growth story in fiscal 2017 and beyond. 
Thank you. And now I'll turn it over to jade.

componenttextpreview: Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for March quarter are available on our website. Now let's take a look at our segment results. At
componenttext:
Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for March quarter are available on our website. Now let's take a look at our segment results. 
At our Media Networks segment, revenues in the quarter were down 3% compared with the prior year. Domestic revenues decreased 4% and international revenues were substantially flat. Excluding a 7% unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues were up 7%, reflecting growth in advertising and affiliate revenues. 
Page 9 of our web deck provides a breakdown of our Media Networks revenue performance. In terms of advertising, worldwide revenues declined 4% in the quarter, domestic revenues were down 5% and international revenues were down 1%. Excluding foreign exchange, which had a 7 percentage point unfavorable impact, international advertising grew 6%, driven by growth in Europe. 
In terms of affiliate revenues, worldwide revenues were down 1%; domestic revenues declined 2% in the quarter, reflecting a modest decline in subscribers and previously disclosed rate adjustment by a major distributor, partially offset by rate increases across the remaining subscriber base. Excluding a 7 percentage point unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues increased 11%, driven by new channel launches, increased subscribers and rate increase. Expenses increased 2% in the quarter. Within operating expenses, programming expenses were up 6%, while distribution and other expenses decreased 10%. SG&A expense decreased 2% in the quarter. The increase in programming costs was due to our ongoing investment in original content. The decrease in SG&A cost was principally due to lower advertising and promotional expenses. 
Within Media Networks adjusted operating income was down 11% for the quarter and the adjusted operating income margin was 33.8%. Decline in operating income was driven by the 3 percentage point decrease in revenue and the 2% increase in expense. 
Moving to Filmed Entertainment. Revenues were down 1% in the quarter principally due to a decrease in home entertainment revenue, partially offset by an increase in license fees. Foreign exchange had a 2 percentage point unfavorable impact on Filmed Entertainment revenue growth. Page 12 of the web presentation provides the breakdown of Filmed Entertainment revenues. 
Theatrical revenues increased 6% due to higher carryover revenues from Daddy's Home and The Big Short, which were both released late in the December quarter, partially offset by lower revenues from the current quarter releases. Home entertainment revenues declined 21%, reflecting lower revenue from catalog nd third-party business subscribers. Revenue from license fees increased 17%, primarily driven by the licensing of certain titles in subscription video-on-demand. 
Filmed Entertainment generated an adjusted operating loss of $136 million in the quarter as compared to income of $1 million last year. The loss in the quarter  primarily reflects the performance of Zoolander 2 and Whiskey Tango Foxtrot. 
In terms of taxes, the year-to-date adjusted effective tax rate was 32.8%, reflecting 100 basis points increase compared to the prior year. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that have already been [indiscernible]. In the quarter, we generated $382 million in free cash flow, which compares to $598 million
componenttext:
Thank you, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that have already been [indiscernible]. In the quarter, we generated $382 million in free cash flow, which compares to $598 million of free cash flow in the March quarter of last year. 
Page 5 of the web deck presentation provides the components of free cash flow. The decline in free cash flow versus the prior year principally due to lower adjusted operating income. 
Moving on to our debt. The debt remains principally fixed rate with an average cost at quarter-end of 4.6%. We ended the quarter with $12.5 billion total debt and $480 million of cash and cash equivalents. 
At the end of the quarter, our leverage ratio was 3.3x. We have $368 million remaining of our outstanding senior -- 6.25% senior notes, which mature on April 30. We plan on paying these notes off. 
Now let's turn to some of the factors impacting the remainder of fiscal 2016. In terms of affiliate revenues, quarterly affiliate revenue will fluctuate according to the timing of transaction and the recognition of revenue related to certain distribution agreements, which are tied to product availability. 
For the fiscal 2016 year, we continue to expect growth in affiliate revenues to be in the low mid-single-digit range. 
For the full year, we continue to expect that Media Networks programming expense growth rate will be in the mid-single-digits. Given the timing of shows coming on air in the back half of the year, we expect programming expense growth to be weighted through the June quarter. Additionally, we expect marketing expense to be higher in the June quarter related to the launch of these shows. In terms of taxes, for 2016, we are forecasting a book tax rate of approximately 32.8%. 
At Paramount, while it has been a difficult first half of the year, we are looking forward to our summer releases, including Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 2 and Star Trek 3. Given the first half performance, we expect the studio to generate a loss in fiscal 2016 [ph]. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to your questions.

componenttext: Thank you, Alexia. Well as we mentioned, we are reducing ad load on several of our network and we believe that we'll improve our brand health overall and help us as we go to the upfront, which is like to be very strong. There is a strong demand in the scatter market and pricing is never strong in the scatter market. But as you point out, we have limited inventory available to take advantage of that right now and what will drive improvement in addition to several of the networks that I mentioned the improving, will be the continuing improvement at Comedy Central and MTV, which are obviously big networks for us and where we have both stepped up our level of programming. We have revitalized the leadership at MTV and a new direction that advertisers welcome, and we will be able to benefit from as we head into the upfront. Additionally, again, related to the upfront, we now have much in-hand capabilities, driven by our Viacom Vantage and our other products, which will help us drive pricing as we go to the upfront and beyond. So we think this is a period where we can, as I mentioned, in my remarks, we hope to see -- it's very early in the quarter but we hope to see some improvement this quarter. And we are very focused on improving the overall brand health and going to advertisers who really view us as the leading way to reach the key demos they want to reach. So we actually feel very optimistic about not just the upfront or what that bodes for the, broadcast year ahead as we continue to seek improvement as the rest of this year unfolds.

Having now reached agreements with all the major distributors, we have a lot of visibility on rate increases under these long-term agreement, which gives us strong visibility. There is by the way and you've seen some of the arranged reports of major distributors in the last few days. There does appear to be some stabilization and subscriber on the part of the distribution committee, which is encouraging. And by the way, that's a byproduct of more work being the in areas like TV Everywhere, customer service and the like. So we certainly now have, especially with the last big major behind us in DISH, good visibility on traditional, which is why I singled that out. And overall we have many opportunities to grow other forms of affiliate revenue, whether it's SVOD platforms, whether it's other over-the-top product or even Swing as part of our recent DISH agreement. So we have some visibility that allows us to protect the mid-single-digits. Of course, where we land on that depends a lot on what impact happens with that forward subscriber counts and the like, but I'm encouraged by the stabilization that appears to be taking hold in the marketplace.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's results for 2016 second quarter. As we move forward, we have several notable areas of strength, including ratings improvement in key network, solid visibility on long-ter
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's results for 2016 second quarter. As we move forward, we have several notable areas of strength, including ratings improvement in key network, solid visibility on long-term affiliate revenue growth, increasing value generated from the growing use of technology and data and continued growth in our international business. We made solid progress in the quarter driving significant change across our brands to increase the value of our content and better position us for the future. 
There are 4 major strategic objectives driving change and future growth at Viacom. First and foremost, we continue to make substantial investments in content, specifically original content, a long-term imperative that is generating clear results and building long-term value. This includes steadily escalating content investments in television and film as well as short-form mobile content. 
Second, we are upgrading and expanding our already substantial data capabilities to deliver more accurate metrics for advertisers and greater monetization potential. We are out in the lead in this area and are beginning to reap the benefit, which will accelerate as we go forward. 
Third, we are maximizing our opportunities for revenue growth with traditional distributors, while moving forward with new forms of distribution. Our content ownership and the popularity of our content on new platforms and social media are providing new options as the ecosystem evolves. 
And fourth, we continue to look at strategic options to enhance our competitive position and unlock the value of our businesses. Our exploration of the strategic minority investor in Paramount is an excellent example as is our continued international expansion. 
Looking at the numbers, in the second quarter, revenues declined 3% to $3 billion. Adjusted operating income was $586 million, and adjusted net earnings from continuing operations were $303 million. Adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations declined to $0.76 per diluted share. 
Turning to Media Networks. Revenues declined 3% to $2.38 billion in the quarter. Ad sales revenues were down 5% in the U.S. While it is early in the quarter, we hope to improve the rate of change in ad sales revenue even as we reduce unit load at several of our network, which bodes well for brand health and future financial performance. This year, we expect a strong upfront, a tripling of Viacom Vantage clients and additional interest in kids, where Viacom has some of its greatest strength. The movie studios are coming to this upfront with an increased number of kids and family-oriented theatrical releases. And as the dominant kids network, this is very positive for Nickelodeon. 
In addition, we have recently launched Viacom Vantage Studio Edition, the first data-driven ad products specifically for the studio category where we see significant opportunities for overall growth. Domestic affiliate revenues in the current quarter decreased 2%, impacted as we had previously discussed at the rate realignment with a major distributor and slight declines in distribution in line with industry trend. SVOD revenues are expected to be more significant in the second half of our fiscal year. 
Based on the long-term deals we've recently closed, we expect to grow affiliate revenues with traditional distributors and overall at mid-single digit rates in 2017 when the rate realignment will be behind us and beyond.  
Our recent renewal with DISH on favorable terms was an important moment for Viacom. In the past year, we have successfully renewed distribution deals with several major distributors representing over 44 million subscribers. We now have long-term deals in place with all of the major distributors and an extended runway for steady affiliate revenue growth. 
We have a real opportunity to build on that momentum. Our networks are highly valued by our cable, satellite and telco partners because they drive substantial live and video-on-demand viewership. In fact, the reach of our networks is vastly underappreciated. We continue to own the largest share of viewership in multiple key demographics on the highly monetizable cable-television platform. Viacom networks combined represent the largest share of cable viewing of any cable family for all viewers, 2+, according to Nielsen. And we gained more share compared to a year ago than any other family of cable networks among viewers 2 to 49, where we have 21% of viewership. We also have the largest share of viewers 18 to 34, also 21%; and 18 to 49 at over 17%. 
The significance of this share shift will become even more evident as new, more robust measurement tools take hold in the market. In addition, our networks and the demos they attract are much desired for OTT streaming service is from new entrants in the industry as well as of those developed by the traditional distributors such as Sling. 
While cable penetration continues to decline across the industry, the penetration of connected devices is growing at a double-digit clip. In fact, 34% of broadband households subscribed to 2 or more paid Internet video services. The Viacom network portfolio is the leader in the U.S. among broadband-only homes and drive significant viewership on long-form platforms like Amazon, Hulu and Roku, as well as on short-form platforms like YouTube and Snapchat. Viacom's strong position as a valued-content provider in both traditional cable and the fast-growing broadband and mobile universe will continue to work in our favor as we lead the content providers into this new world. 
It gives us great confidence that our brands' connections with valuable audiences are as strong as ever. We will maintain our focus on improving traditional ratings and also work to increase monetization in broadband power distribution by collaborating with our partners on subscription models and advertising features that will make these platforms more economically attractive. 
One of the ways we're meeting these challenges is by continuing to expand our data and ad technology capability, exemplified by today's announcement with Roku. Among connected device owners, Roku homes have the highest reach, average days used and hours used per day. In fact, Roku usage is greater than Xbox, Chromecast and Apple TV combined, and that lead is accelerating. This first-of-its-kind partnership will allow us to leverage aggregate data from Roku, enabling sophisticated ad targeting at an unprecedented scale in the TV environment. Through this partnership, we can offer better, more targeted ad product. We also have a financial investment in Roku. 
Combined with partnerships with comScore, TiVo, Symphony, Snapchat and several others, a continuing relationship with Nielsen and our expanding internal expertise, we're building a platform that's second to none. There is no question that Internet delivery is here to stay, and we continue to grow quickly through new and bigger OTT and SVOD services as well as an improving TV Everywhere experience. 
Now turning to a brief update on our Media Networks. We are rejuvenating and repositioning several of our network and seeing positive results. Viacom had 8 of the top 30 ad-supported cable networks in the 2+ demo and 9 of the top 30 in the 18 to 49 demo, 1 more than last year in each. We also had the highest number of top 20 cable series among core demos. 
Nickelodeon continues its leading performance, taking the #1 spot in 2 to 11 for 37 consecutive weeks and pulling away from its competitors on a total day and head-to-head basis. Blaze and the Monster Machines was the #1 program across all television with young kids for the second consecutive quarter. Among kids 2 to 11, Nickelodeon on the top 2 animated shows, SpongeBob SquarePants and ALVINNN!!! and 4 of the top 5 programs throughout the quarter. On the consumer product side, PAW Patrol is the #1 preschool property with every mass retailer. The property is a success in nearly every license product category, including preschool toys, where it is #1, apparel, home goods and accessories. 
VH1's rating were the best in 6 years with strong double-digit gains across the board. At Spike, Lip Sync Battle remains the most-watched original series in the channel's history, and Season 2 continues to deliver a big and a broad audience. It's also a global hit now in more than 120 countries. 
Bellator, which Spike acquired in 2011, is another global success story. Currently the fastest-growing combat sports franchise worldwide, Bellator is averaging 1.2 million viewers this year, a 45% increase over 2015. Bellator held its first European event in Torino, Italy this month with 2 additional international events planned this year, the first in London and airing on Viacom's Channel 5, and the second in Israel. We expect Bellator to grow into a significant Viacom asset in its own right. 
At MTV, overall ratings remain soft but MTV's programming continues to capture substantial audience share with 5 of the top 25 programs on cable among viewers 12 to 34. Under new overall and programming leadership, MTV is committed to bringing more live music and music-inspired programming to the network. Last week, MTV put on a reimagined upfront event that was very warmly received by the ad community. The upcoming slate features 14 new series and specials fueled by top-tier producing talent like Mark Burnett and including Wonderland, the network's first weekly live music performance series in nearly 20 years that debuts this fall. 
At Comedy Central, changing viewing patterns continue to impact ratings but declines narrowed significantly versus the prior quarter. Comedy Central continues to develop hit new programming, including this quarter's Not Safe With Nikki Glaser and is returning popular multiplatform shows, such as Inside Amy Schumer, Broad City, Tosh.0 and Another Period. The turnaround of MTV and Comedy Central will be a driver of our advertising revenue recovery as we head into our next fiscal year. 
Viacom's International Media Networks performance continues to be strong with even more growth on the horizon. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange, advertising revenues increased 6% in the quarter, and affiliate revenues rose 11% in the quarter. This is an important and underappreciated part of our portfolio that has grown significantly and now includes the Paramount Channel, Channel 5, Viacom 18, Spike, Comedy as well as even better, more localized MTV and Nickelodeon networks. Ratings are strong in our international brands particularly MTV. 
In India, Viacom and our JV partner have 16 networks and a country-leading position. We are showing strong growth in regional market and have recently launched VOOT, an advertising supported VOD platform that will house COLORS, MTV and Nick content as well as original long and short-form content. 
In the U.K., our brands continue to show solid growth. Channel 5 reached its highest share ever in the 16 to 34 demo in the quarter. And MTV, Nick and Comedy all posted double-digit share increases. Nickelodeon remains the #1 kids' channel group in pay television. 
International markets also give us a valuable opportunity to experiment with new digital platforms and monetization strategy. For example, Play Plex, a flexible app-based distribution platform for all of Viacom's global brands can help our pay-TV operator partners create a great TV Everywhere experience for consumers or be distributed as an over-the-top service. We are particularly excited about Play Plex as an authenticated or direct-to-consumer mobile product in markets without cable and pay-TV infrastructure. 
Paramount results were disappointing this quarter, largely due to 2 titles that performed below expectations. We look forward to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles in the current quarter and Star Trek Beyond, Ben-Hur, Jack Reacher 2, Rings and several other promising titles later in the year. Paramount Television continues to make rapid progress with 15 shows ordered to production and an additional 10 set up at networks, including Maniac, a comedy starting Emma Stone and Jonah Hill for Netflix. 
Turning to EPIX. We are looking forward to the introduction of its first 2 original scripted series in the fall, including Paramount's Berlin Station. EPIX has the youngest audience of all of the major premium services and was the fastest-growing premium network in the U.S., growing more than 35% year-over-year in 2015. 
The process of identifying a strategic minority investor in Paramount is continuing and on track to securing agreement by the end of June. The strategic and valuation possibilities are compelling. Like the entire media industry, the motion picture business is evolving. A strong strategic partner for Paramount, particularly one that provides international and/or technological cloud and expertise will provide important benefits to both Paramount and Viacom. 
In summary, we are creating more and more original programming under revitalized network leadership, and that is bearing fruit both in the U.S. and abroad. We have secured renewals with all of our major U.S. distribution affiliates. We are entering into partnerships with a number of new market entrants, including Snapchat, Roku, comScore and more. Our international expansion will provide opportunities to drive significant value and growth for Viacom for the foreseeable future. And Paramount is poised for renewed success, driven by a full slate and a vibrant television business. Our entire management team is completely focused on putting the building blocks for growth in place this year. We have a smart strategy and are investing in our properties in the U.S. and around the world, setting us up to become a growth story in fiscal 2017 and beyond. 
Thank you. And now I'll turn it over to Wade.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our March quarter are available on our website. Now let's take a look at our segment results. At
componenttext:
Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our March quarter are available on our website. Now let's take a look at our segment results. 
At our Media Networks segment, revenues in the quarter were down 3% compared with the prior year. Domestic revenues decreased 4%, and international revenues were substantially flat. Excluding a 7% unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues were up 7%, reflecting growth in advertising and affiliate revenues. 
Page 9 of our web deck provides a breakdown of our Media Networks revenue performance. In terms of advertising, worldwide revenues declined 4% in the quarter, domestic revenues were down 5%. And international revenues were down 1%. Excluding foreign exchange, which had a 7 percentage point unfavorable impact, international advertising grew 6%, driven by growth in Europe. 
In terms of affiliate revenues, worldwide revenues were down 1%. Domestic revenues declined 2% in the quarter, reflecting a modest decline in subscribers at a previously disclosed rate adjustment -- major distributor, partially offset by rate increases across the remaining subscriber base. Excluding a 7 percentage point unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues increased 11%, driven by new channel launches, increased subscribers and rate increase. Expenses increased 2% in the quarter. Within operating expenses, programming expenses were up 6%, while distribution and other expenses decreased 10%. SG&A expense decreased 2% in the quarter. The increase in programming costs was due to our ongoing investment in original content. The decrease in SG&A cost was principally due to lower advertising and promotional expenses. 
Within Media Networks adjusted operating income, it was down 11% for the quarter. And the adjusted operating income margin was 33.8%. Decline in operating income was driven by the 3 percentage point decrease in revenue and the 2% increase in expense. 
Moving to Filmed Entertainment. Revenues were down 1% in the quarter principally due to a decrease in home entertainment revenue, partially offset by an increase in license fees. Foreign exchange had a 2 percentage point unfavorable impact on Filmed Entertainment revenue growth. Page 12 of the web presentation provides the breakdown of Filmed Entertainment revenues. 
Theatrical revenues increased 6% due to higher carryover revenues from Daddy's Home and The Big Short, which were both released late in the December quarter, partially offset by lower revenues from the current quarter releases. Home entertainment revenues declined 21%, reflecting lower revenue from catalog and third-party business subscribers. Revenue from license fees increased 17%, primarily driven by the licensing of certain titles in subscription video-on-demand. 
Filmed Entertainment generated an adjusted operating loss of $136 million in the quarter as compared to income of $1 million last year. The loss in the quarter primarily reflects the performance of Zoolander 2 and Whiskey Tango Foxtrot. 
In terms of taxes, the year-to-date adjusted effective tax rate was 32.8%, reflecting 100 basis points increase compared to the prior year. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt, as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed. In the quarter, we generated $382 million in free cash flow, which compares to $598 million
componenttext:
Thank you, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt, as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed. 
In the quarter, we generated $382 million in free cash flow, which compares to $598 million of free cash flow in the March quarter of last year. Page 5 of the web deck presentation provides the components of free cash flow. The decline in free cash flow versus the prior year is principally due to lower adjusted operating income. 
Moving on to our debt. It remains principally fixed rate with an average cost at quarter end of 4.6%. We ended the quarter with $12.5 billion total debt and $480 million of cash and cash equivalents. At the end of the quarter, our leverage ratio was 3.3x. We have $368 million remaining over our outstanding senior -- 6.25% senior notes, which mature on April 30. We plan on paying these notes off. 
Now let's turn to some of the factors impacting the remainder of fiscal 2016. In terms of affiliate revenues, quarterly affiliate revenue will fluctuate according to the timing of transaction and the recognition of revenue related to certain distribution agreements, which are tied to product availability. 
For the fiscal 2016 year, we continue to expect growth in affiliate revenues to be in the low mid-single-digit range. For the full year, we continue to expect that Media Networks' programming expense growth rate will be in the mid-single digits. Given the timing of shows coming on air in the back half of the year, we expect programming expense growth to be weighted through the June quarter. Additionally, we expect marketing expense to be higher in the June quarter related to the launch of these shows. In terms of taxes, for 2016, we are forecasting a book tax rate of approximately 32.8%. 
At Paramount, while it has been a difficult first half of the year, we are looking forward to our summer releases, including Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 2 and Star Trek 3. Given the first half performance, we expect the studio to generate a loss in fiscal 2016.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to your questions.

componenttextpreview: Thank you, Alexia. Well, as we mentioned, we are reducing ad load on several of our network. And we believe that we'll improve our brand health overall and help us as we go into the upfront, which we expect to be very strong. There is strong demand in the
componenttext: Thank you, Alexia. Well, as we mentioned, we are reducing ad load on several of our network. And we believe that we'll improve our brand health overall and help us as we go into the upfront, which we expect to be very strong. There is strong demand in the scatter market, and pricing is very strong in the scatter market. But as you point out, we have limited inventory available to take advantage of that right now and what will drive improvement in addition to several of the networks that I mentioned improving will be the continuing improvement at Comedy Central and MTV, which are obviously big networks for us and where we have both stepped up our level of programming. We have revitalized the leadership at MTV and a new direction that advertisers welcome and we will be able to benefit from as we head into the upfront. Additionally, again, related to the upfront, we now have much enhance capabilities driven by our Viacom Vantage and other products, which will help us drive pricing as we go to the upfront and beyond. So we think this is a period where we can -- as I mentioned in my remarks, we hope to see -- it's very early in the quarter. But we hope to see some improvement this quarter. And we are very focused on improving the overall brand health and going to advertisers who really view us as the leading way to reach the key demos they want to reach. So we certainly feel very optimistic about not just the upfront or what that bodes for the broadcast year ahead as we continue to seek improvement as the rest of this year unfold.
