componenttext: Yes, so I talked about the mid-single digits for 2017 and beyond. Having now reached agreements with all the major distributors, we have a lot of visibility on rate increases under these long-term agreement, which give us strong visibility. There is by the way -- and you've seen some of the arranged reports by major distributors in the last few days. There does appear to be some stabilization and subscriber on the part of the distribution community, which is encouraging. And by the way, I think that's a byproduct of more work being done in areas like TV Everywhere, customer service and the like. So we'll see it -- we  certainly now have, especially with the last big major behind us in DISH, good visibility on traditional, which is why I singled that out. And then overall, we have many opportunities to grow other forms of affiliate revenue whether it's SVOD platforms, whether it's other over-the-top product or even Sling as part of our recent DISH agreement. So we have some visibility that allows us to project the mid-single digits. Of course, where we land on that depends a lot on what, in fact, happens. We'd go forward on subscriber counts and the like, but I'm encouraged by the stabilization that appears to be taking hold in the marketplace.

componenttext: As far as Sling, I'm going to let DISH make its consumer announcement but I will say that we have a broad array of network. We did choose to withhold the Nickelodeon network for now from the Sling platform, and we will evaluate that as it goes forward. And as far as other virtual MVPDs, what we have learned from discussions with various players is that there are different points of view on what the consumer offerings ought to be. And in many cases, particularly MVPDs, to the extent they're exploring this, they're looking at it as a gateway to the broader offering of networks that you might feel as more traditional or even though delivery is getting less traditional and that they're using digital delivery in TV Everywhere kind of offerings to consumers. As far as the Comcast issue relating to repairing, we continue to deal with that privately with Comcast at this point rather than make any further comment on that which we continue to contest.

componenttext: Nothing can be further from the truth. We are very pleased with the terms. We are -- as I've mentioned in the past and I know people have been -- I've been talking about DISH, have been talking about it for 1.5 years. I said all along we have had long and strong relationship with DISH. I had indicated that we were going to -- we were confident that the deal was going to be renewed. And I'm proud to say that we were able to renew it on good terms without our networks being taken away from consumers unlike about 20 situations involving other programmers, that distributor over the last few years. And we are set up with DISH in a very constructive relationship with growth in rates over term on both the traditional platform and Sling. And we have also provided in our DISH deal a lot of new functionality that relates to TV Everywhere and video-on-demand as we, of course, brought the agreement up-to-date. And I think that will benefit DISH's consumers and again, reinforce the ecosystem with this important distributor. And we will continue to look for new ways to work together as we go forward, as we do with all of our [indiscernible]. And we deliver, particularly valuable audiences -- gives them our strength in the demos I talked about in the earnings remarks. You cannot reach millennials in the way that we do. We have the leading families. So if one wants to drive services that appeal to millennials and some of these new over-the-top products are entry points into media for millennials, we provide core services as demonstrated by the deal that we did.

And remember that as I've said previously, the over 3/4 of advertising comes from our top 100 advertisers. And we are in this upfront expecting to triple the number of Vantage participants to approximately 33 players. Take the 33 against the top 100 and think of the 32 as concentrated in the top 50. componenttext: So as far as the domestic market, we have the 3 major distributors in Netflix, Amazon and Hulu, and then we have some others emerging or in discussions, all of whom are looking for new compelling content as it is increasingly competitive environment among them. So we continue to see that as a growing opportunity. We are being selective in what program we make available and what the windows are. And as I've talked about in prior earnings calls, we are differentiating among types of programming based on the performance that we see. And in many cases, we see a presence for our shows at SVOD by our seasons, for example, as being an important marketing driver for new season, a good vehicle for catch-up and other things of that nature. On the international marketplace, clearly, it is a fast-growing opportunity. It is a significant opportunity in many countries where there's not a robust traditional delivery market. And importantly, we are seeing a lot of these SVOD services are local, not the ones that we talk about here in the U.S. There's a lot of local competition in the marketplace. The last time I looked at it, for example, in a country like China, there are 7 major, and I'm sure several others beyond the 7 majors that I was looking at, SVOD players that are local. But it's not just China. In many other places, you have local MVPDs that are setting up robust services. They watched what happened in the U.S. and so they got ahead of some of the U.S. players that have now expanded globally. So in many countries, we're seeing the opportunity for us be greater with local players than the U.S.-based services that are "exporting abroad." At the same time, we're doing a fair amount of business with the U.S.-based ones as they looked for international growth. So overall, it's a good opportunity for us. And since you bring up international, the opportunity to distribute content on various mobile services, particularly in countries where there's not a real good established pay television infrastructure is also a significant area throughout as we look...

Good morning, everyone, and thank you for taking the time to join as for our March quarter earnings call. Joining me for today's discussion are Philippe Dauman, our Chief -- our Executive Chairman, President and CEO; Tom Dooley, our Chief Operating Officer; and Wade Davis, our Chief Financial Officer.
Please note that in addition to our press release, we have slides and trending schedules containing supplemental information available on our website.  I want to refer you to Page #2 in the web presentation and remind you that certain statements made on this call are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in more details on our filings with the SEC.
Today's remarks will focus on adjusted results. Reconciliations for non-GAAP financial information discussed on this call can be found in our earnings release or on our website.
And now, I'll turn the call over to Philippe.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's results for 2016 second quarter. As we move forward, we have several notable areas of strength, including ratings improvement in key network, solid visibility on long-ter
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us to discuss Viacom's results for 2016 second quarter. As we move forward, we have several notable areas of strength, including ratings improvement in key network, solid visibility on long-term affiliate revenue growth, increasing value generated from the growing use of technology and data and continued growth in our international business. We made solid progress in the quarter driving significant change across our brands to increase the value of our content and better position us for the future. 
There are 4 major strategic objectives driving change and future growth at Viacom. First and foremost, we continue to make substantial investments in content, specifically original content, a long-term imperative that is generating clear results and building long-term value. This includes steadily escalating content investments in television and film as well as short-form mobile content. Second, we are upgrading and expanding our already substantial data capabilities to deliver more accurate metrics for advertisers and greater monetization potential. We are out in the lead in this area and are beginning to reap the benefit, which will accelerate as we go forward. 
Third, we are maximizing our opportunities for revenue growth with traditional distributors, while moving forward with new forms of distribution. Our content ownership and the popularity of our content on new platforms and social media are providing new options as the ecosystem evolves. And fourth, we continue to look at strategic options to enhance our competitive position and unlock the value of our businesses. Our exploration of a strategic minority investor in Paramount is an excellent example as is our continued international expansion. Looking at the numbers, in the second quarter, revenues declined 3% to $3 billion. Adjusted operating income was $586 million, and adjusted net earnings from continuing operations were $303 million. Adjusted diluted earnings per share from continuing operations declined to $0.76 per diluted share. 
Turning to Media Networks. Revenues declined 3% to $2.38 billion in the quarter. Ad sales revenues were down 5% in the U.S. While it is early in the quarter, we hope to improve the rate of change in ad sales revenue even as we reduce unit load at several of our network, which bodes well for brand health and future financial performance. This year, we expect a strong upfront, a tripling of Viacom Vantage clients and additional interest in kids, where Viacom has some of its greatest strength. The movie studios are coming to this upfront with an increased number of kids and family-oriented theatrical releases. And as the dominant kids network, this is very positive for Nickelodeon.  In addition, we have recently launched Viacom Vantage Studio Edition, the first data-driven ad products specifically for the studio category where we see significant opportunities for overall growth. 
Domestic affiliate revenues in the current quarter decreased 2%, impacted as we had previously discussed at the rate realignment with a major distributor and slight declines in distribution in line with industry trend. SVOD revenues are expected to be more significant in the second half of our fiscal year. Based on the long-term deals we've recently closed, we expect to grow affiliate revenues with traditional distributors and overall at mid-single digit rates in 2017 when the rate realignment will be behind us and beyond.  
Our recent renewal with DISH on favorable terms was an important moment for Viacom. In the past year, we have successfully renewed distribution deals with several major distributors representing over 44 million subscribers. We now have long-term deals in place with all of the major distributors and an extended runway for steady affiliate revenue growth. We have a real opportunity to build on that momentum. Our networks are highly valued by our cable, satellite and telco partners because they drive substantial live and video-on-demand viewership. In fact, the reach of our networks is vastly underappreciated. We continue to own the largest share of viewership in multiple key demographics on the highly monetizable cable-television platform. Viacom networks combined represent the largest share of cable viewing of any cable family for all viewers, 2+, according to Nielsen. And we gained more share compared to a year ago than any other family of cable networks among viewers 2 to 49, where we have 21% of viewership. We also have the largest share of viewers 18 to 34, also 21%; and 18 to 49 at over 17%. 
The significance of this share shift will become even more evident as new, more robust measurement tools take hold in the market. In addition, our networks and the demos they attract are much desired for OTT streaming services from new entrants in the industry as well as of those developed by the traditional distributors such as Sling. 
While cable penetration continues to decline across the industry, the penetration of connected devices is growing at a double-digit clip. In fact, 34% of broadband households subscribed to 2 or more paid Internet video services. The Viacom network portfolio is the leader in the U.S. among broadband-only homes and drives significant viewership on long-form platforms like Amazon, Hulu and Roku, as well as on short-form platforms like YouTube and Snapchat. Viacom's strong position as a valued-content provider in both traditional cable and the fast-growing broadband and mobile universe will continue to work in our favor as we lead the content providers into this new world. 
It gives us great confidence that our brands' connections with valuable audiences are as strong as ever. We will maintain our focus on improving traditional ratings and also work to increase monetization in broadband power distribution by collaborating with our partners on subscription models and advertising features that will make these platforms more economically attractive. One of the ways we're meeting these challenges is by continuing to expand our data and ad technology capability, exemplified by today's announcement with Roku. Among connected device owners, Roku homes have the highest reach, average days used and hours used per day. In fact, Roku usage is greater than Xbox, Chromecast and Apple TV combined, and that lead is accelerating. This first-of-its-kind partnership will allow us to leverage aggregate data from Roku, enabling sophisticated ad targeting at an unprecedented scale in the TV environment. Through this partnership, we can offer better, more targeted ad product. We also have a financial investment in Roku. 
Combined with partnerships with comScore, TiVo, Symphony, Snapchat and several others, a continuing relationship with Nielsen and our expanding internal expertise, we're building a platform that's second to none. There is no question that Internet delivery is here to stay, and we continue to grow quickly through new and bigger OTT and SVOD services as well as an improving TV Everywhere experience. 
Now turning to a brief update on our Media Networks. We are rejuvenating and repositioning several of our network and seeing positive results. Viacom had 8 of the top 30 ad-supported cable networks in the 2+ demo and 9 of the top 30 in the 18 to 49 demo, 1 more than last year in each. We also had the highest number of top 20 cable series among core demos. 
Nickelodeon continues its leading performance, taking the #1 spot in 2 to 11 for 37 consecutive weeks and pulling away from its competitors on a total day and head-to-head basis. Blaze and the Monster Machines was the #1 program across all television with young kids for the second consecutive quarter. Among kids 2 to 11, Nickelodeon owned the top 2 animated shows, SpongeBob SquarePants and ALVINNN!!! and 4 of the top 5 programs throughout the quarter. On the consumer product side, PAW Patrol is the #1 preschool property with every mass retailer. The property is a success in nearly every license product category, including preschool toys, where it is #1, apparel, home goods and accessories. 
VH1's ratings were the best in 6 years with strong double-digit gains across the board. At Spike, Lip Sync Battle remains the most-watched original series in the channel's history, and Season 2 continues to deliver a big and a broad audience. It's also a global hit now in more than 120 countries. Bellator, which Spike acquired in 2011, is another global success story. Currently the fastest-growing combat sports franchise worldwide, Bellator is averaging 1.2 million viewers this year, a 45% increase over 2015. Bellator held its first European event in Torino, Italy this month with 2 additional international events planned this year, the first in London and airing on Viacom's Channel 5, and the second in Israel. We expect Bellator to grow into a significant Viacom asset in its own right. 
At MTV, overall ratings remain soft but MTV's programming continues to capture substantial audience share with 5 of the top 25 programs on cable among viewers 12 to 34. Under new overall and programming leadership, MTV is committed to bringing more live music and music-inspired programming to the network. Last week, MTV put on a reimagined upfront event that was very warmly received by the ad community. The upcoming slate features 14 new series and specials fueled by top-tier producing talent like Mark Burnett and including Wonderland, the network's first weekly live music performance series in nearly 20 years that debuts this fall. 
At Comedy Central, changing viewing patterns continue to impact ratings but declines narrowed significantly versus the prior quarter. Comedy Central continues to develop hit new programming, including this quarter's Not Safe With Nikki Glaser and its returning popular multiplatform shows, such as Inside Amy Schumer, Broad City, Tosh.0 and Another Period. The turnaround of MTV and Comedy Central will be a driver of our advertising revenue recovery as we head into our next fiscal year. 
Viacom's International Media Networks performance continues to be strong with even more growth on the horizon. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange, advertising revenues increased 6% in the quarter, and affiliate revenues rose 11% in the quarter. This is an important and underappreciated part of our portfolio that has grown significantly and now includes the Paramount Channel, Channel 5, Viacom 18, Spike, Comedy as well as even better, more localized MTV and Nickelodeon networks. Ratings are strong in our international brands, particularly MTV. 
In India, Viacom and our JV partner have 16 networks and a country-leading position. We are showing strong growth in regional market and have recently launched VOOT, an advertising supported VOD platform that will house COLORS, MTV and Nick content as well as original long and short-form content.  In the U.K., our brands continue to show solid growth. Channel 5 reached its highest share ever in the 16 to 34 demo in the quarter. And MTV, Nick and Comedy all posted double-digit share increases. Nickelodeon remains the #1 kids' channel group in pay television. 
International markets also give us a valuable opportunity to experiment with new digital platforms and monetization strategy. For example, Play Plex, a flexible app-based distribution platform for all of Viacom's global brands can help our pay-TV operator partners create a great TV Everywhere experience for consumers or be distributed as an over-the-top service. We are particularly excited about Play Plex as an authenticated or direct-to-consumer mobile product in markets without cable and pay-TV infrastructure. 
Paramount results were disappointing this quarter, largely due to 2 titles that performed below expectations. We look forward to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles in the current quarter and Star Trek Beyond, Ben-Hur, Jack Reacher 2, Rings and several other promising titles later in the year. Paramount Television continues to make rapid progress with 15 shows ordered to production and an additional 10 set up at networks, including Maniac, a comedy starting Emma Stone and Jonah Hill for Netflix. 
Turning to EPIX. We are looking forward to the introduction of its first 2 original scripted series in the fall, including Paramount's Berlin Station. EPIX has the youngest audience of all of the major premium services and was the fastest-growing premium network in the U.S., growing more than 35% year-over-year in 2015. The process of identifying a strategic minority investor in Paramount is continuing and on track to securing agreement by the end of June. The strategic and valuation possibilities are compelling. Like the entire media industry, the motion picture business is evolving. A strong strategic partner for Paramount, particularly one that provides international and/or technological cloud and expertise will provide important benefits to both Paramount and Viacom. 
In summary, we are creating more and more original programming under revitalized network leadership, and that is bearing fruit both in the U.S. and abroad. We have secured renewals with all of our major U.S. distribution affiliates. We are entering into partnerships with a number of new market entrants, including Snapchat, Roku, comScore and more. Our international expansion will provide opportunities to drive significant value and growth for Viacom for the foreseeable future. And Paramount is poised for renewed success, driven by a full slate and a vibrant television business. Our entire management team is completely focused on putting the building blocks for growth in place this year. We have a smart strategy and are investing in our properties in the U.S. and around the world, setting us up to become a growth story in fiscal 2017 and beyond. 
Thank you. And now I'll turn it over to Wade.

componenttextpreview: Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our March quarter are available on our website. Now let's take a look at our segment results. At
componenttext:
Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and web presentation summarizing the results for our March quarter are available on our website. Now let's take a look at our segment results. 
At our Media Networks segment, revenues in the quarter were down 3% compared with the prior year. Domestic revenues decreased 4%, and international revenues were substantially flat. Excluding a 7% unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues were up 7%, reflecting growth in advertising and affiliate revenues. 
Page 9 of our web deck provides a breakdown of our Media Networks revenue performance. In terms of advertising, worldwide revenues declined 4% in the quarter, domestic revenues were down 5% and international revenues were down 1%. Excluding foreign exchange, which had a 7 percentage point unfavorable impact, international advertising grew 6%, driven by growth in Europe. 
In terms of affiliate revenues, worldwide revenues were down 1%. Domestic revenues declined 2% in the quarter, reflecting a modest decline in subscribers and a previously disclosed rate adjustment [indiscernible] major distributor, partially offset by rate increases across the remaining subscriber base. Excluding a 7 percentage point unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues increased 11%, driven by new channel launches, increased subscribers and rate increase. 
Expenses increased 2% in the quarter. Within operating expenses, programming expenses were up 6%, while distribution and other expenses decreased 10%. SG&A expense decreased 2% in the quarter. The increase in programming costs was due to our ongoing investment in original content. The decrease in SG&A cost was principally due to lower advertising and promotional expenses.  Within Media Networks adjusted operating income, it was down 11% for the quarter. And the adjusted operating income margin was 33.8%. Decline in operating income was driven by the 3 percentage point decrease in revenue and the 2% increase in expense. 
Moving to Filmed Entertainment. Revenues were down 1% in the quarter principally due to a decrease in home entertainment revenue, partially offset by an increase in license fees. Foreign exchange had a 2 percentage point unfavorable impact on Filmed Entertainment revenue growth. Page 12 of the web presentation provides the breakdown of Filmed Entertainment revenues. 
Theatrical revenues increased 6% due to higher carryover revenues from Daddy's Home and The Big Short, which were both released late in the December quarter, partially offset by lower revenues from the current quarter releases. Home entertainment revenues declined 21%, reflecting lower revenue from catalog and third-party distribution partners. Revenue from license fees increased 17%, primarily driven by the licensing of certain titles in subscription video-on-demand.  Filmed Entertainment generated an adjusted operating loss of $136 million in the quarter as compared to income of $1 million last year. The loss in the quarter primarily reflects the performance of Zoolander 2 and Whiskey Tango Foxtrot.  In terms of taxes, the year-to-date adjusted effective tax rate was 32.8%, reflecting a 100 basis point increase compared to the prior year. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt, as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed. In the quarter, we generated $382 million in free cash flow, which compares to $598 million of
componenttext:
Thank you, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt, as well as the seasonal factors impacting our 2016 fiscal year that haven't already been discussed. In the quarter, we generated $382 million in free cash flow, which compares to $598 million of free cash flow in the March quarter of last year. Page 5 of the web deck presentation provides the components of free cash flow. The decline in free cash flow versus the prior year is principally due to lower adjusted operating income. 
Moving on to our debt. It remains principally fixed rate with an average cost at quarter end of 4.6%. We ended the quarter with $12.5 billion total debt and $480 million of cash and cash equivalents. At the end of the quarter, our leverage ratio was 3.3x. We have $368 million remaining over our outstanding 6.25% senior notes, which mature on April 30. We plan on paying these notes off. 
Now let's turn to some of the factors impacting the remainder of fiscal 2016. In terms of affiliate revenues, quarterly affiliate revenue will fluctuate according to the timing of transaction and the recognition of revenue related to certain distribution agreements, which are tied to product availability.  For the fiscal 2016 year, we continue to expect growth in affiliate revenues to be in the low mid-single-digit range. For the full year, we continue to expect that Media Networks' programming expense growth rate will be in the mid-single digits. Given the timing of shows coming on air in the back half of the year, we expect programming expense growth to be weighted through the June quarter. Additionally, we expect marketing expense to be higher in the June quarter related to the launch of these shows. In terms of taxes, for 2016, we are forecasting a book tax rate of approximately 32.8%. 
At Paramount, while it has been a difficult first half of the year, we are looking forward to our summer releases, including Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 2 and Star Trek 3. Given the first half performance, we expect the studio to generate a loss in fiscal 2016.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to your questions.

componenttext: Thank you, Alexia. Well, as we mentioned, we are reducing ad load on several of our networks. And we believe that we'll improve our brand health overall and help us as we go into the upfront, which we expect to be very strong. There is strong demand in the scatter market, and pricing is very strong in the scatter market. But as you point out, we have limited inventory available to take advantage of that right now and what will drive improvement in addition to several of the networks that I mentioned improving will be the continuing improvement at Comedy Central and MTV, which are obviously big networks for us and where we have both stepped up our level of programming. We have revitalized the leadership at MTV and a new direction that advertisers welcome and we will be able to benefit from as we head into the upfront. Additionally, again, related to the upfront, we now have much enhanced capabilities driven by our Viacom Vantage and other products, which will help us drive pricing as we go to the upfront and beyond. So we think this is a period where we can -- as I mentioned in my remarks, we hope to see -- it is very early in the quarter. But we hope to see some improvement this quarter. And we are very focused on improving the overall brand health and going to advertisers who really view us as the leading way to reach the key demos they want to reach. So we certainly feel very optimistic about not just the upfront or what that bodes for the broadcast year ahead as we continue to seek improvement as the rest of this year unfold.

So we'll see it -- we certainly now have, especially with the last big major behind us in DISH, good visibility on traditional, which is why I singled that out. And then overall, we have many opportunities to grow other forms of affiliate revenue whether it's SVOD platforms, whether it's other over-the-top product or even Sling as part of our recent DISH agreement. componenttext: As far as Sling, I'm going to let DISH make its consumer announcement but I will say that we have a broad array of network. We did choose to withhold the Nickelodeon network for now from the Sling platform, and we will evaluate that as it goes forward. And as far as other virtual MVPDs, what we have learned from discussions with various players is that there are different points of view on what the consumer offerings ought to be. And in many cases, particularly MVPDs, to the extent they're exploring this, they're looking at it as a gateway to the broader offering of networks that you might view as more traditional or even though delivery is getting less traditional in that they're using digital delivery in TV Everywhere kind of offerings to consumers. As far as the Comcast issue relating to repairing, we continue to deal with that privately with Comcast at this point. I'd rather not make any further comment on that which we continue to contest.

componenttext: Nothing could be further from the truth. We are very pleased with the terms. We are -- as I've mentioned in the past and I know people have been talking about DISH, have been talking about it for 1.5 years. I said all along we have had long and strong relationship with DISH. I had indicated that we were going to -- we were confident that the deal was going to be renewed. And I'm proud to say that we were able to renew it on good terms without our networks being taken away from consumers, unlike about 20 situations involving other programmers at that distributor over the last few years. And we are set up with DISH in a very constructive relationship with growth in rates over term on both the traditional platform and Sling. And we have also provided in our DISH deal a lot of new functionality that relates to TV Everywhere and video-on-demand as we, of course, brought the agreement up-to-date. And I think that will benefit DISH's consumers and again, reinforce the ecosystem with this important distributor. And we will continue to look for new ways to work together as we go forward, as we do with all of our affiliates. And we deliver, particularly valuable audiences -- gives them our strength in the demos I talked about in the earnings remarks. You cannot reach millennials in the way that we do. We have the leading families. So if one wants to drive services that appeal to millennials and some of these new over-the-top products are entry points into media for millennials, we provide core services as demonstrated by the deal that we did.

componenttext: Well, as far as the television operation, it's a startup. We started Paramount Television less than 2 years ago from scratch. So the vast majority of the shows were basically picked up over the last, certainly over the last year with a lot -- over the last several months. And as shows have been green lit, they've been making a number of announcements. Some of them are for our own network, like School of Rock, which has been ordered for a second season on Nickelodeon as it's off to a great start. We're looking at an original series for TV Land coming from Paramount Television. We have an original series slated for Spike from Paramount. And this fall, we have Berlin Station on EPIX. That's just our own network. We -- I mentioned Maniac on Netflix. We have other series that's for our SVOD services. We have series on HBO. We have series on Fox. We had GREASE LIVE. That was very successful on Fox. We have series on Turner Network. We really have series across the board. Some of it, original concepts and some of them based on titles in the Paramount library. So there are many, many opportunities to create new series just starting with our own library of great film piles that can be turned into a television series. It, of course, allows us also to sell in the global marketplace. So we were very happy with the rapid list off. And we think as series get on air, get into multiple seasons, it will be a great leg for Paramount and an important driver of long-term performance for Paramount. And it's certainly an interesting aspect of this as we explore a strategic transaction. Vantage, I'll let Tom supplement what I have to say on Vantage, but it's been certainly a key part of the conversation with our major branded advertisers. And remember that as I've said previously, the over 3/4 of advertising comes from our top 100 advertisers. And we are in this upfront expecting to triple the number of Vantage participants to approximately 33 players. Take the 33 against the top 100 and think of the 32 [ph] as being concentrated in the top 50. So it's a substantial part of our upfront discussions. And we talked about Vantage. componenttextpreview: So as far as the domestic market, we have the 3 major distributors in Netflix, Amazon and Hulu, and then we have some others emerging or in discussions, all of whom are looking for new compelling content as it is increasingly competitive environment among
componenttext: So as far as the domestic market, we have the 3 major distributors in Netflix, Amazon and Hulu, and then we have some others emerging or in discussions, all of whom are looking for new compelling content as it is increasingly competitive environment among them. So we continue to see that as a growing opportunity. We are being selective in what programming we make available and what the windows are. And as I've talked about in prior earnings calls, we are differentiating among types of programming based on the performance that we see. And in many cases, we see a presence for our shows at SVOD by our seasons, for example, as being an important marketing driver for a new season, a good vehicle for catch-up and other things of that nature. On the international marketplace, clearly, it is a fast-growing opportunity. It is a significant opportunity in many countries where there's not a robust traditional delivery market. And importantly, we are seeing a lot of these SVOD services are local, not the ones that we talk about here in the U.S. There's a lot of local competition in the marketplace. The last time I looked at it, for example, in a country like China, there are 7 major, and I'm sure several others beyond the 7 majors that I was looking at, SVOD players that are local. But it's not just China. In many other places, you have local MVPDs that are setting up robust services. They watched what happened in the U.S. and so they got ahead of some of the U.S. players that have now expanded globally. So in many countries, we're seeing the opportunity for us be greater with local players than the U.S.-based services that are "exporting abroad." At the same time, we're doing a fair amount of business with the U.S.-based ones as they looked for international growth. So overall, it's a good opportunity for us. And since you bring up international, the opportunity to distribute content on various mobile services, particularly in countries where there's not a real good established pay television infrastructure is also a significant area of growth as we look into the years ahead.

componenttext: Well, as far as I've mentioned in my remarks on the affiliate revenue, the adjustment for the AT&T direct renewal plays itself out through our fiscal year. That's why I referenced that being behind us as we head into 2017. And we don't break out specifically the categories outside of [ph] revenue growth. And as Tom mentioned in his remarks, there's a certain choppiness to the product -- the revenue recognition based on product availability in the SVOD space. And before Tom responds to your questions as it relates to the expense items that you talked about, yes, we always have -- I just want to make an overall comment. As far as our programming expense and investment, we always have invested in programming and grown our investment in programming. It is the source of opportunity for us to monetize in different platforms around the world. And by the way, as our international business grows, they also are generating original programming. Some of which is finding its way directly into the U.S. or formats. We have formats originating here, originating in our international networks. And we think, at this stage, based on the conversations that I have had, that we will have a compelling result that will be both a strategic driver, reflect the significant value of Paramount, which after all is one of the greatest studios in Hollywood with 100-plus year history. So I think today's announcement is just a validation of the value of the highest form of content, which is motion picture content. And as I mentioned earlier, at Paramount, we have the great growth opportunity created by a new television production operation that in and of itself is a growth business for the future of Paramount.

Good morning, everyone, and thank you for taking the time to join us for our June quarter earnings call. Joining me for today's discussion are Philippe Dauman, our Executive Chairman, President and CEO; Tom Dooley, our Chief Operating Officer; and Wade Davis, our Chief Financial Officer. 
Please note that in addition to our press release, we have slides and trending schedules containing supplemental information available on our website. 
I want to refer you to Page #2 in the web presentation and remind you that certain statements made on this call are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in more detail in our filings with the SEC. 
Today's remarks will focus on adjusted results. Reconciliations for non-GAAP financial information discussed on this call can be found in our earnings release or on our website. 
And now I'll turn the call over to Philippe.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Viacom's third quarter earnings call. As you know, since our last call, we have been subject to controversy relating to governance, which has obviously created an overhang for our company. Last week,
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Viacom's third quarter earnings call. As you know, since our last call, we have been subject to controversy relating to governance, which has obviously created an overhang for our company. Last week, courts in Massachusetts and Delaware rejected motions to dismiss, allowed discovery to proceed and scheduled trials to take place in October. We view these favorable court rulings as positive steps that move us ahead to a resolution. In light of the litigation, we won't be able to comment further on this topic during today's call. 
Meanwhile, Viacom continues to focus on making progress against our strategic plan. We are increasing our investments in more and more original content across multiple platforms, extending our lead in sophisticated data products, building engaging new consumer experiences through innovative, thoughtful distribution partnerships as well as new consumer products, recreation and hospitality initiatives, expanding our formidable international presence and forging new strategic paths, including a potential partnership to unlock the value of Paramount and provide competitive advantages for the studio and Viacom overall. These initiatives are the most recent manifestation of a careful, comprehensive and consistent vision for Viacom that we have pursued since I became CEO in 2006 to focus on original content, enhance our distribution revenues and build a robust international business while adapting to change. That job is never done, nor is it easy. There are disruptive challenges in our industry, particularly for those companies like Viacom that focus on younger demographics, but we are having increasing success at several of our brands. And we are leveraging those learnings to accelerate that success at other properties. 
Wade and Tom will go into the numbers in a moment. First, let me review some of the drivers of our results for the quarter and what lies ahead. In ad sales, we concluded a strong upfront. More advertisers committed early instead of waiting for the scatter market later when inventory is scarce. This movement and ratings progress at core networks as well as our new advertising products resulted in mid to high single-digit price and volume increases. Our end-to-end, data-driven marketing solutions continue to help us lead the way and advance advertising. And our proprietary, predictive engine, Vantage, is in even more demand by sophisticated marketing partners. We expected to triple the number of Vantage deals from last year to this year. And we exceeded that goal. In this upfront, we will secure 35 to 40 Vantage deals with our partners. Significantly, more than half are based on comScore metrics, signaling a welcome market shift to alternative currencies. 
In addition, we held the industry's first-ever data front, where we showcased our data capabilities and announced Vantage Intent powered by long-time partner, American Express. This exclusive, unprecedented collaboration resulted in the first product to tap American Express's unique data using predictive analytics to help marketers reach consumers even earlier in their purchase consideration process. 
These are all powerful examples of how we have transformed our company over the last several years. 
On the affiliate side, in the third quarter, we signed long-term deals with both DISH and Cox, both with solid annual rate increases. The decline in affiliate revenues was impacted by several factors, including the lapping of a large SVOD deal last year. As we disclosed in June, we expected to complete a significant SVOD agreement in the third quarter of this year, but recent uncertainty, coupled with our evaluation of various new distribution opportunities, have led to a slowdown of these discussions. 
As we have discussed, despite the continuing impact of changing audience behaviors and preferences, I am pleased to say that, in the June quarter, we've stabilized our ratings and several of our networks are leading the industry in their categories. Viacom holds 6 of the top 30 ad-supported cable networks. And our family of networks captures the most share in nearly every demo, 2 plus, 2 to 11, 2 to 49, and most importantly, 18 to 49 and 18 to 34. And through the 5 weeks of the fourth quarter, our revenue weighted ratings are up. Among viewers 2-plus, in the third quarter, VH1 delivered the biggest ratings gain of any of the 30 largest non-U.S. cable networks and Nick Jr. had the largest year-over-year ratings increase of any rated network. And we're also seeing strong traction across platforms. Viewership on our mobile apps is up 26% over the third quarter of last year. 
Nickelodeon story is a highlight and a perfect example of our strategy across the company to broaden our revenue base and drive audience engagement. Nickelodeon's ratings increased 6% in the quarter, and it extended its #1 ranking among kids 2 to 11 to 52 straight weeks, increasing an already substantial lead to over 20% over our biggest competitor in the quarter in that demo. And the best news is that much of Nickelodeon's success is driven by a broad lineup of popular programming that is new and fresh from a variety of genres, including animation, live-action and preschool. Leading the way is Henry Danger, which is the quarter's #1 show among kids 2 to 11 and 6 to 11, averaging 2.4 million total viewers per episode. Nick's newest animated series, the Loud House, has become a runaway hit and is averaging almost 2 million viewers per episode. In the current quarter, Kids Choice Sports outpaced last year's strong performance, up double digits, and like all of Nickelodeon's tentpole events, continues to be an extremely attractive opportunity for advertisers. On digital platforms, Nick continues to see strong year-over-year growth in video viewing, up almost 20% for the quarter across Nick and Nick Jr. sites and apps. 
Moving into the consumer products world. Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Blaze and the Monster Machines, PAW Patrol and Shimmer and Shine are all strong consumer success stories with outstanding growth potential. Additionally, our recreation and hospitality efforts continue to come online. Finally, the SpongeBob Musical has opened in Chicago to very positive critical buzz. We're looking forward to bring it to New York next fiscal year. This is the new Nickelodeon -- and her talented creative team have been building. And we couldn't be more excited or proud of the great turnaround they have engineered fueled by strategic insight, continued investment and unwavering faith in their capabilities. There is no kid's brand with more magic than Nickelodeon right now. And we believe their broad portfolio of legitimate hits will drive significant diversified growth for years to come. 
VH1 is also a great story and a blueprint of our investment in great content, acceleration of the development process and smart use of data can drive improved performance. VH1 expanded its ratings gain in Q3, finishing up 33%. That's right. 33%, the fourth consecutive quarter of growth. VH1 is making aggressive investments in distinctive programming and drilling in on what VH1 fans want. Love & Hip Hop Atlanta continues to be a juggernaut and rank as the #1 reality show in cable. In fact, VH1 has 2 of the top 5 reality cable shows. Hip Hop Honors, which aired in July, was the highest-rated VH1 tentpole in 15 years with over 3 million viewers. We're building on these proven properties in the current quarter with Love & Hip Hop Hollywood and the new Amber Rose Show, which we took straight to air and developing in real-time using sophisticated applications of audience science. In addition, our marketing and scheduling teams at VH1 are applying proprietary learnings from Viacom's data insight capabilities to drive additional viewership and engagement, helping our hit shows gain even more audience traction. VH1 is leading the charge, and we are exploring ways that these strategies can be applied seamlessly to our other adult networks. 
Comedy Central's ratings improved significantly towards the end of the third quarter, and the network is up year-over-year in the fourth quarter so far. New leadership is reinvigorating the brand, and we are looking forward to a new season of Drunk History, the premiere of a new standup series produced by and starring Kevin Hart and the Comedy Central Roast of Rob Lowe. And of course, Kyle, Cartman and the Southpark Gang are back for a historic 20th season premiering next month. Their anniversary celebration was a hit at Comic Con. The extraordinary longevity is a true testament to the creative excellence of Trey and Matt, the deep devotion of the show's fans and the outstanding team at Comedy Central. 
The BET awards also continued its strong run, ranking as the #1 cable award show among audiences 18 to 49 for the 2015-2016 broadcast season, claiming the top spot for the second consecutive year. Among African-American viewers, the program has ranked as television's #1 awards show for the last 15 years. 
Moving on to our international Media Networks. We continue to see a strong performance by Bob and his team with both advertising and affiliate revenues increasing at double-digit levels, excluding the impact of foreign exchange. Looking ahead, we remain intently focused on expanding and leveraging our diverse set of assets. We continue to diversify and strengthen our brand portfolio, reflecting demographic and market-specific opportunities. 10 years ago, when I became CEO, our international portfolio was singularly focused on youth. Today, our portfolio is radically different, with more breadth and depth, with a focus on the global 6: Nick, Nick Jr, MTV, Comedy Central, the Paramount Channel and SPIKE. In fact, the Paramount Channel, the largest ad-supported movie channel in the world, is now in 93 million homes outside the U.S. 
Our first major push beyond MTV was the Nickelodeon portfolio, which now reaches 283 million homes internationally. And we are now a major player in the adult demographic, which is significantly larger than our kids or youth segments. Comedy Central, our third global brand, is in 180 million homes outside the U.S. We now have 11 Paramount channels, the largest ad-supported international film channel in the world, built from scratch in just 4 short years. And we've begun the rollout of SPIKE, which is doing very well for us in the 3 markets we've launched. In just the past fiscal year alone, Viacom International Media Networks launched 15 new channels, with particular focus on the Middle East and Africa this past quarter. 
Of course, we also have 2 flagship local brands in the general entertainment space, Channel 5 in the U.K. and Colors in India, and both are operating extremely well. Again, 2 significant and highly promising businesses that did not exist at Viacom 10 years ago. 
In total, our channels now reached 3.8 billion aggregate subscribers, more than any other family of networks in the world. And looking ahead, there is very significant opportunity. 
The second priority is evolving from being simply an exporter of U.S. content to becoming a global content producer. We still bring a lot of high-performing domestic Viacom content overseas markets, particularly on the kid's side, but we are also increasing production of Viacom International Media Networks for our networks around the world. In fact, there are 7 in-house productions currently underway for Nickelodeon's global channels. 
Third, and perhaps most exciting for its obvious significance to our entire portfolio, we are redefining what it means to be a TV network. Across our international footprint, pay-TV penetration is approximately 40%, presenting us with attractive opportunities to exploit our digital products, including the Viacom Play Plex platform. Viacom Play Plex provides TV Everywhere functionality to cable customers, subscription services for mobile operators as well as direct-to-consumer opportunities. We've got the infrastructure, the brands, the content and the products to quickly scale the way we get content to consumers across 180 countries. 
Finally, Viacom International Media Networks is already generating significant revenues through consumer products, and we see a lot of potential in recreation, particularly retail, hotels and life experiences. These opportunities exist throughout our portfolio, but we are putting particular focus on Asia, the Middle East and Latin America. 
Now let's talk about Paramount. There is no question the studio has had a rough go at the box office recently. But as they always do, we expect fortunes to turn. As you know, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows did not meet our expectations. But there's significant bright spots at the studio. In particular, Paramount Television continues to grow rapidly, delivering new titles in the quarter, including Berlin Station for EPIX. Paramount Television will be a continuing source of growth, augmenting the revitalization of Paramount's theatrical slate. Again, it is worth noting that Paramount's television production is a business that also did not exist a few years ago. We made it a priority to return Paramount to the television production business. And we made it happen. 
In the current quarter, we have the critically acclaimed Star Trek Beyond, which is still opening across territories around the world in the next several weeks. Later in the quarter, Paramount will open Florence Foster Jenkins with Meryl Streep and Hugh Grant and Ben-Hur. And coming in the first quarter of 2017, Jack Reacher: Never Go Back, starring Tom Cruise. 
Regarding our exploration of the sale of a 49% interest in Paramount to a strategic buyer, as we previously disclosed, we have narrowed the process down to a handful of prospects. The process has slowed down in recent weeks, but we have reason to believe the favorable court developments last week will create a better environment that will allow us to progress with several parties toward a highly beneficial transaction to present to our board. 
To conclude, we continue to focus on our strategic initiatives and are confident that there will be a significant fruit as we prepare for our next fiscal year. The ratings at our domestic Media Networks are improving. Our successful upfront and continued leadership in data-driven products will allow us to take advantage of continued ratings improvements at key networks. Our distribution landscape will improve as we lap the fiscal 2016 consolidation impacts and SVOD comps and we continue to grow and monetize new platforms. Our international networks will continue to expand in scope and value. And Paramount will see better days ahead with improved film slate performance, television production, and we hope, a groundbreaking strategic alliance. 
And with that, I will turn it over to Wade.

Thanks, Philippe. Before I take you through our operating results, I want to note that our earnings release and webcast presentation summarizing the results for our June quarter are available on our website. 
From a total company perspective, revenues grew 2% to $3.1 billion. Adjusted operating income was $769 million and adjusted net earnings were $419 million. Adjusted diluted earnings per share declined to $1.05 in the quarter.
Now let's take a look at our segments results. At our Media Networks segment, revenues in the quarter were down 3% compared with the prior year. Domestic revenues decreased 7%. International revenues were up 13%. Excluding a 5% unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues were up 18%. [ph] Double-digit growth in advertising affiliate and our [indiscernible]
Page 9 of our web deck provides a breakdown of our Media Networks revenue. 
In terms of advertising, worldwide revenues declined 1% [ph] in the quarter. Domestic revenues were down 4%. International revenue was [indiscernible]  Excluding foreign exchange, which had a 6 percentage point unfavorable impact, international advertising grew 19% [ph] driven by growth in [indiscernible] 
In terms of affiliate revenues worldwide revenues were down 8%. Domestic revenues declined 10% in the quarter, reflecting a difficult comparison [indiscernible] available under certain distribution agreements in the June quarter of last year. 
Excluding a 3 percentage point unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international revenues increased 12%, driven by [indiscernible] of certain distribution agreements. 
Expenses increased 11% in the quarter with an operating expenses, programming expenses were up 12% while distribution and other expenses decreased 8%. SG&A expense increased 13% in the quarter. The increase in programming costs is due to our continuing investment in original content. The increase in SG&A cost was [indiscernible] due to higher [indiscernible] 
Media Networks adjusted operating income was down 22% in the quarter and the adjusted operating margin was 34.7%, and a decline in operating income was driven by the 3% decrease in revenues and the 11% increase. 
Moving to Filmed Entertainment. Revenues were up 30% in the quarter principally due to increases in theatrical revenue and license fees. Page 12 of the web presentation provides the breakdown of the Filmed Entertainment revenues. Theatrical revenues increased to $91 million due to the release of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows in the quarter. License fees increased 39%, principally driven by the licensing of certain titles and subscription video-on-demand as well as contributions from our television production business. Filmed Entertainment generated an adjusted operating loss of $26 million in the quarter as compared to income of $48 million last year. The loss in the quarter reflects the underperformance of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows. 
In terms of taxes, the year-to-date adjusted effective tax rate was 32.8%, reflecting a 100 basis point increase as compared to the prior year. 
And with that, I would like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt as well as factors impacting our September quarter of fiscal 2016 that haven't already been discussed. For the quarter, we generated $90 million of free cash flow, which compares to $300 million o
componenttext:
Thanks, Wade. I'm going to cover our cash flow, our debt as well as factors impacting our September quarter of fiscal 2016 that haven't already been discussed. 
For the quarter, we generated $90 million of free cash flow, which compares to $300 million of free cash flow in the June quarter of last year. Page 5 of the web deck presentation provides the components of free cash flow. The decline in free cash flow versus the prior year was principally due to lower operating income and higher working capital utilization, which was due to net investment in film product. This was partially offset by lower cash taxes. 
In terms of our debt, it remains principally fixed-rate with an average cost at quarter-end of 4.6%. During the quarter, we repaid $368 million of our outstanding 6.25% senior notes that came due in April. We ended the quarter with $12.4 billion of total debt and $192 million of cash and cash equivalents. At the end of the quarter, our leverage ratio was 3.6x. 
Now let's turn to some of the factors impacting the remainder of fiscal 2016. In terms of affiliate revenue, quarterly affiliate revenue will fluctuate according to the timing of transactions and the recognition of revenue related to certain distribution agreements, which are tied to product availability. For fiscal year 2016, we expect domestic affiliate revenues to decline at low to mid-single-digit rate. However, due to continuing uncertainty around the timing and completion of an SVOD distribution agreement, affiliate revenues could decline at mid to high single-digit rates. For the full year, we expect that Media Networks programming expense growth rate will be in the low to mid-single digits. And Paramount, given the underperformance of certain films in the current year's slate, we expect to generate an operating loss for the September quarter as well as for the full fiscal year. 
In terms of taxes, for 2016, we are forecasting a book tax rate of approximately 32.8%. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to your questions. Operator?

componenttext: Well, yes, obviously, it's somewhat of a distraction, but we are not deterred from pursuing strategic initiatives I described. Our brands are what drive our business. So to some extent, probably the biggest impact has been on the ability to move forward rapidly on the Paramount transaction, which had initially been targeted to result in an agreement about a month ago. So that's certainly been slowed down. But as I indicated in my prepared remarks, they continue. And I hope that we will reach a conclusion on that, that will be beneficial to the company in due course. So that's really the principal impact, apart from the general distraction naturally. But it does not deter us from pursuing our international growth. It does not deter us from getting affiliate agreements concluded. It does not deter us from producing great new programming. It does not deter our management teams across our networks to be really focused on building our ratings. It does not deter us in getting a successful upfront. It does not deter us in developing continued industry-leading marketing products. Did not deter us from finding new ways to distribute our content to our audiences everywhere they are on every device they utilize and does not deter us from continually entering into new partnerships with companies like Roku, Snapchat and comScore and on and on. So we're focused. We are driving value for this company. And we view any difficulties that we face as a challenge that we will overcome. We'll be creative and overcoming and really search for every opportunity. I touched on some opportunities that will take a while to unfold. But they're pretty exciting. When you think about the power of the Nickelodeon brand, the fact that we have ratings success for so many new shows -- yes, people used to talk about our being so dependent on SpongeBob, but now we have such an array of shows. And each of those shows has consumer products opportunity around the world, particularly as we have grown our Nickelodeon footprint. And speaking of SpongeBob, this musical is really great now. When it hits Broadway, it could be an opportunity, not just inherently, but to revitalize that property. So the opportunities are manyfold. We have a strong management team. As you know, over the last 1.5 years, we have reorganized significantly. We have new leadership at several of our networks. You're seeing the effects already that the new leadership is bringing, VH1 being the perfect example that I cited. So yes, it's a distraction. But in the scope of time, it will be viewed as temporary. And our strategic initiatives continue unabated.

componenttextpreview: Well, we have seen -- in the U.K., we have great stronghold countries, and we continue to build scale both organically with our 6 global brands. And by the way, we have many other brands that we're driving, whether it's BET or different Nick brands and so
componenttext: Well, we have seen -- in the U.K., we have great stronghold countries, and we continue to build scale both organically with our 6 global brands. And by the way, we have many other brands that we're driving, whether it's BET or different Nick brands and so forth. But so -- when I'm referring to 6 brands, I'm talking the ones that are global and reach every continent and continue to grow across as many countries in those continents as possible. But when you have in the U.K., we bought Channel 5, very attractive acquisition. We revitalized the brand. I mean, literally, we changed the brand logo, and we have invested in programming. And we have a leading position there. It's gained share. We've also looked to build scale in other countries. And it's paying off. So we are -- we have really been building a platform the last several years, which is really now coming to maturity. We just have a lot of opportunities to expand there. We're focused on building value. I've said it over and over again. And in India, which is not a consolidated entity, continues to grow at extraordinary rates. We continue to grow at extraordinary rates year after year for years to come. We continue to add networks there. It's a network -- it's a country with a lot of opportunity, large population, fastest economic growth rate in the world today, the top growing economy in the world with a population that just loves entertainment. So our sector is growing much faster than GDP. So I believe, I talked about the last 10 years and how it's grown to this point, I believe over the next 10 years our international assets are going to have a value that potentially surpasses the entire value of the company today on the trajectory that we have.
