componenttext: Okay, thanks. This is Kern here. I'll take Vantage Intent for a second. You're right. It's an incredible partnership. We have an exclusive deal with American Express that makes us the only television publisher that can use the predictions that come out of their platform. Essentially, the way that, that works is American Express has this unique asset in their closed-loop network and they can look at patterns that reveal shifts or pending shifts in life stages that can help folks in a number of different categories target people who are about to make a change, about to start purchasing differently or about to make some major investments. And those persuadable audiences, people who are about to embark on moving in with a partner, purchasing a new vehicle, growing their family, those are really, really exciting moments. And they fit really well with television advertising because it's an opportunity to shape brand perceptions and drive purchase patterns for the long term. So this tie-up with American Express, where they generate segments that we can exclusively enable for the television marketplace, creates tremendous, tremendous opportunity for advertisers, where you've got these long consideration cycles and long-term purchase patterns that are about to be established.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And to your second question, I really do believe it's the most significant opportunity facing not only our company but our industry today. And if I was to sum it up with one important enabler, I will use the word focus, right. And it's -- we have, th
componenttext: Yes. And to your second question, I really do believe it's the most significant opportunity facing not only our company but our industry today. And if I was to sum it up with one important enabler, I will use the word focus, right. And it's -- we have, through the last decade, built a true multinational organization, which has connected leadership around the world. So we're set up to execute. We have a strategy that says this is a real opportunity. And everyone, particularly on the distribution side but more broadly, is aware of that, educated on that and focused on that in our organization. And as we build, we talk about this what we call VIMN, Viacom International Media Networks, core 6. And it's about focusing our investments on content and, call it, broad marketing and promotion, including what you're doing in social and the like, on those brands so that they're as strong as possible and have a solid footing regardless of the distribution platform. Clearly, we're very focused on the MVPD space. But the good news about the VMVPD space is increasingly, these are platforms that are operated and therefore consistent with some of the philosophies that are in the -- that are built to pay-TV industry. So by focusing on it, having the right product mix, making sure your teams are really running at it, that is the key enabler because there is not a shadow of a doubt that the distribution infrastructure, particularly through mobile, will be there. And there's not a shadow of a doubt that the appetite for consumers is there. So it's really about prioritizing it and filling it.

componenttext: So I believe you've got to look at everything. Again, we start with we have a long history in the pay-TV business. We have deep partnerships around the world with pay-TV operators. And we believe there's incremental opportunity there. And we believe that they are supportive of content businesses such as ours. So we come with a lens of looking for a pay-TV-friendly strategy. And in the last quarter, we've done a mix of deals in traditional pay. By the way, you can see that today, we announced that Spike is going 24 hours in the Netherlands with Ziggo. Ziggo is a Liberty Global company. We have a very significant relationship and partnership with Liberty Global. And they're obviously a key customer of ours. And it's a partnership that works for both of us. And I think the indication is we continue to do more things with them. That's very healthy. At the same time, on the OTT side, many of these partner -- many of these platforms increasingly are, let's use the word related, to a traditional player. The canary in the coal mine on that probably was Sky NOW in the U.K. And really all the distributors around the world, I think it's fair to say, are looking at playing in that space. Then when you look at the traditional -- traditional is a bad word, the SVOD category and you think of aggregators, we will look at that on an opportunity-by-opportunity basis, consider specifics about a market and a specific player and a specific app and determine what we want to do there. They certainly have a role in the world from a consumer perspective, but we are looking at it as part of a holistic strategy. And that will dictate what we do.

componenttext: Well, we'd contribute, but I think it's going to be a function of the pictures more than anything else. componenttext: I think the only thing -- I mean just to get back to your question, Michael. There is nothing more systemic embedded in the underperformance this year. And I think, as Tom said, we have a high degree of confidence in the turnaround that Paramount is getting kind of at or around breakeven.

componenttext: Sure. That sounded like that was for me. So a couple of things, as I stated in my remarks, I am -- I've been chartered by the board to focus on running Viacom as an independent company. That is very much my mandate and what they've asked me to do. As part of doing that, I believe we've got to bring the team together and unlock really what I'm convinced is a whole lot of great thinking throughout the organization and at all levels of the organization, and then identify through that the ideas we want to bring to life. When you look at it from the top-down, there's some clear weakness areas, as we've talked about, MTV. Comedy Central, we have some recent good trend lines in Trevor. By the way, Trevor Noah is significantly stronger internationally than Jon was. So the Trevor Noah franchise is a great one. And the fact that he's really connecting through this election cycle is a very exciting development. And also South Park's 20th, 20-year-old franchise and the new episodes are doing extremely well. And that's another global franchise. So there's some good stuff starting to happen at Comedy Central. And obviously, we'd like to see more happen. On the Paramount side, as Tom and Wade indicated and I've been speaking with Brad regularly and just starting to get into that, obviously the film slate will be highly important. We're also going to see what we can do on the marketing side in the short term to see if that is an incremental opportunity. So I think there's a clear set of priorities and I'm convinced that by working with the team, we will unlock a good action plan. Obviously, part of that will be content investments. But I think it's important that based on -- you understand that based on my experience, a lot of this is about mix of investments, not about you have to spend dramatically more money necessarily. Again, our international experience shows that you can deliver very significant audiences in genres other than high-dollar scripted programming. So I think mix will continue to be an opportunity.

So I was wondering if you could reconcile those for us.

componenttext: Look, I think that the pictures that we put into production over the past several years, we had several big pictures that underperformed dramatically relative to what we had thought they would do. A good example of that is Zoolander. Another example of that is Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Those films really had losses that were outsized and really created the hole in the bucket that we had in the previous year, consequential hole in the bucket. And I think we have looked at the greenlight process. I think Brad Grey and his team, he's made changes on his team and is focused on putting in place the kind of movies that we think will result in a significant turnaround and refocused on bottom line profitability and the type of movies that he's putting into production. And as I said, as we look down the road here and I think as we get through the end of this quarter, you'll see Paramount having a much better performance in the pictures that it's putting into the marketplace. And I think the most important thing to look for is how they perform relative to the competition. Then I think you'll see Paramount beginning to stand up and distinguish itself in that regard.

componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for taking the time to join us for our September quarter earnings call. Joining me for today's discussion are: Tom Dooley; Bob Bakish, who is currently President and CEO of our Global Entertainment Group, who will assume the role of President and CEO of Viacom on November 15; Wade Davis, our Chief Financial Officer; and Kern Schireson, our EVP of Data Strategy & Consumer Intelligence. Please note that in addition to our press release, we have slides and trending schedules containing supplemental information available on our website. 
I want to refer you to Page #2 in the web presentation and remind you that certain statements made on this call are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in more detail in our filings with the SEC. 
Today's remarks will focus on adjusted results. Reconciliations for non-GAAP financial information discussed on this call can be found in our earnings release or on our website. 
And now I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Good morning, everyone. We've got a lot to cover today. And along with Wade, I am pleased to welcome Kern Schireson, who will provide an overview and update on our industry-leading data strategy. Kern has worked at Viacom for several years to
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Good morning, everyone. We've got a lot to cover today. And along with Wade, I am pleased to welcome Kern Schireson, who will provide an overview and update on our industry-leading data strategy. Kern has worked at Viacom for several years to develop and then expand Viacom's capabilities in this area. It's an exciting and quickly growing part of our core business. 
You'll also be hearing from Bob Bakish, who will discuss the recent achievements coming out of our International Media Networks business and his views on the company overall. 
As you know, Bob has been selected to lead the company as CEO. And I believe that there is nobody better suited for that role. Not only has he built critical scale in our complex international businesses, but he has driven technological and strategic innovation while consistently increasing profitability. With that track record, his deep knowledge of our overall business and his appreciation of the people and culture that have made Viacom great, he's exactly the right leader for Viacom's next chapter. 
The special committee of our Board of Directors is continuing to work with its financial and legal advisers to explore the merits of a combination with CBS, but we will not have an update for you today on that process. But we want to be very clear that Viacom will continue to operate for the long term with a strategy of driving growth, building our core businesses and positioning the company for success in the years ahead. 
We released our financials earlier today, which were towards the higher end of the guidance we provided in September. On the Media Networks side of the business, ratings headwinds and our strategic decision to reduce unit loads at some of our networks put pressure on advertising growth in the quarter. However, the reinvigorated high-performing networks, like Nickelodeon and VH1, have shown that we can generate ad revenue quickly as ratings rebound. And we have brought new management to MTV and Comedy Central to kick-start rating recoveries at those properties. 
In addition, we are significantly increasing our incremental revenues driven by next-generation ad products that are not defined by the traditional currencies. And we are working with the MVPDs on further expanding addressable digital ad insertion at scale. Bob will talk in great detail about our international business, but we are seeing solid strength in those ad markets. Outside the U.S., our ad revenues increased 6% in the quarter, excluding the impact of foreign exchange, driven by -- primarily by strong growth in Europe. 
On a macro level, the advertising marketplace is very good right now, leading to high demand for inventory across all of our networks. Our upfront was strong and scatter in the December quarter continues to look good. We're seeing spending coming out of digital and back into the TV marketplace, which is absorbing inventory and driving price improvements. All of these factors give us confidence in our Q1 results. And we expect to deliver an approximate 500-basis-point improvement over the year-over-year decline in Q4. 
On the affiliate side, we faced challenging comps in the quarter related to a large contribution from an SVOD deal that we accounted for in Q4 2015. Absent the impact of SVOD, on our core traditional affiliate revenue growth, it was essentially flat. However, we're looking ahead with confidence with most of our distribution partners committed to long-term deals at attractive rates and our continued growth in cable share in the quarter. As OTT options continue to grow, we are extremely optimistic about the particular value of Viacom's younger-skewing networks in those offerings. We are approaching each of those opportunities very strategically with a view to driving the most long-term value for the portfolio overall. 
The popularity of these services makes it increasingly difficult to measure consumption. So we've been working to fine-tune our internal metrics to capture all points of monetization and monetizable viewing, including linear, cable VOD and SVOD. Based on this analysis, the consumption of Viacom Media Networks' content across all the domestic linear and digital platforms is increasing on an absolute basis and up 3% in the quarter year-over-year. 
One of the offerings we're very enthusiastic about is DIRECTV NOW. It delivers a robust bundle with 11 Viacom networks in its 100-network portfolio. We view it as a complementary offering to the marketplace, opening up new options for a generation of young consumers who love our programming but have a resistance to signing up with a traditional cable-delivered bundle. We are also working with other existing distribution partners to define new ways to make content available to them on an increasing number of platforms. Looking ahead to the first quarter, we expect to see an increase in our domestic affiliate growth to low single digits, which assumes the impact of a low single-digit decline in the overall cable subscriber universe. 
Moving on to quickly touch upon some of our key networks. Nickelodeon continues to thrive, extending its winning streak to 5 straight quarters at #1 total day with kids 2 to 11 and kids 2 to 5 with a double-digit lead against its 2 largest competitors. Nick's success can't be overstated. The network owned the top 6 shows on TV for kids 2 to 11 in the quarter, including the overall #1 program, The Thundermans. The quarter's top animated program for this demo, the Loud House, is one of the fastest-growing kids' hits, having launched in May at #1 and stayed on top since then. We're in season 2 already. And to meet the audience's demand for this homegrown Nickelodeon show, we have already announced the pickup of season 3. It's a great example of our commitment to quick, assertive investments to keep our most popular content on the air and fresh, which has been -- which we've been applying more and more aggressively to our growing number of Nickelodeon hits. 
Moving offscreen. Nick is actively expanding its recreational offerings to serve the whole family with initiatives like the 5-star luxury Nick Resort in Punta Cana, Dominican Republic, and the fast-selling family show, PAW Patrol Live!, based on this year's top preschool show. In consumer products, Nickelodeon continues to have great success with lines based on Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and PAW Patrol. Products for Blaze and the Monster Machines and Shimmer and Shine just hit shows this summer and the demand is rising fast, particularly for Shimmer and Shine, which was a Halloween costume favorite this year, a traditional indicator of a property's growing popularity. 
VH1 continues to build on its upward momentum, closing out the quarter with 3 of the top non-sports cable shows and #1-rated reality show, Love & Hip Hop: Atlanta. For the fiscal year, VH1 boasts the fastest-growing growth among cable's top 20 and has delivered ratings increases in 5 consecutive quarters. Chris McCarthy has done an incredible job of driving success at VH1. And last month, we added oversight of MTV to his portfolio. He's fired up about the turnaround opportunities there and we're expecting big things from him. 
And a quick note about Comedy Central, which has been a key focus of ours. South Park has opened its 20th season with the highest ratings it's had for several years. The episodes that aired in the fourth quarter were up 27% over the previous season. And the season premiere was the show's highest-rated episode in a decade. We're also seeing more and more momentum behind Trevor Noah as audience continues to build. The election has put The Daily Show front and center again as Trevor has delivered his highest monthly ratings in October and was the highest-rated and most-watched daily late-night talk show among millennial men. We are projecting that fiscal Q1 is going to be his best-rated quarter ever. 
And finally, the upcoming film slate from Paramount Pictures includes an incredible lineup of filmmakers and stars. This November, the studio will release the critically-acclaimed film, Arrival, starring Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner, as well as Allied, starring Brad Pitt and Marion Cotillard. In December, the studio will release the comedy, Office Christmas Party, starring Jennifer Aniston, along with Denzel Washington's Fences and Martin Scorsese's highly anticipated, Silence, based on the acclaimed novel. It's a very strong slate. At Paramount TV, Berlin Station is already in production on seasons 2 and 3 for EPIX. And Shooter, starring Ryan Phillippe and executive produced by Mark Wahlberg, premieres November 15 on USA. It's a quickly growing business and currently Paramount has 30 shows in development. 
Now let's turn the call over to Wade for more about the numbers.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Today, I'm going to cover our operating results, our cash flow and our capital structure, including steps we've taken to address our near-term maturities and liquidity needs. I will also speak to seasonal factors impacting our fiscal 2017.
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Today, I'm going to cover our operating results, our cash flow and our capital structure, including steps we've taken to address our near-term maturities and liquidity needs. I will also speak to seasonal factors impacting our fiscal 2017. 
Looking at the full year on a total company basis. Viacom generated $12.5 billion of revenue, $2.7 billion of adjusted operating income, $1.2 billion of operating free cash flow and $3.68 of adjusted earnings per share. For the September quarter, total company revenues were $3.2 billion and adjusted operating income was $538 million. Adjusted net earnings were $273 million and adjusted diluted earnings per share was $0.69 for the quarter. 
Now let's take a look at our segment results. At our Media Networks segment, revenues for the quarter were down 11% compared to the prior year. Domestic revenues decreased 14%, and international revenues were up 2%. Excluding an 11 percentage point unfavorable foreign currency impact, international revenues were up 13%, reflecting double-digit growth in affiliate and ancillary revenues. Page 8 of our web deck provides a breakdown of our Media Networks revenue performance. 
In terms of advertising, worldwide revenues declined 8% in the quarter. Domestic revenues were down 8% and international revenues were down 7%. Excluding foreign exchange, which had a 13 percentage point unfavorable impact, international advertising grew 6%, driven by continued growth in Europe. 
In terms of affiliate revenues, worldwide revenues in the quarter were down 16%. Domestic revenues declined 19% in the quarter, principally reflecting lower revenues from SVOD arrangements as we made a strategic decision to reduce the amount of programming we license to these distributors. International affiliate revenues increased 7% in the quarter. Excluding an 8 percentage point unfavorable impact from foreign currency, international affiliate revenues increased 15%, driven by new channel launches, increased subscribers, rate increases and the completion of certain SVOD arrangements. 
Expenses decreased 2% in the quarter. Within operating expenses, programming expense was 5% lower while distribution and other expense decreased 20%. SG&A expense increased 9% in the quarter. The decrease in programming expense in the quarter was principally driven by the timing of airing of original programming. The decline in distribution and other expense primarily reflects lower participations in residuals related to lower SVOD revenue. The increase in SG&A cost was principally due to severance and other employee-related costs. 
Media Networks' adjusted operating income for the quarter was $750 million and the adjusted operating income margin was 30%. The decline in adjusted operating income was driven by the 11% decline in revenues, partially offset by the 2% decrease in revenues. 
Moving to Filmed Entertainment. Revenues in the quarter were down 24%, principally due to the decrease in theatrical revenues. Page 11 of the web presentation provides a breakdown of Filmed Entertainment revenues. Theatrical revenues decreased to $203 million due to the difficult comparisons to the strong international performance of Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation in the September quarter of last year. Filmed Entertainment generated an adjusted operating loss of $137 million in the quarter. The decline versus the prior-year quarter reflects lower revenues as well as a previously disclosed $115 million programming impairment charge. 
In terms of taxes, the full year adjusted effective tax rate was 31.7%, reflecting a 50 basis point increase as compared to the prior year. 
In terms of our debt, it remains principally fixed rate with an average cost at quarter-end of 4.6%. We had $11.9 billion of total debt and $379 million of cash and cash equivalents. At the end of the quarter, our leverage ratio was 3.9x. We took several steps to address our near-term maturities and liquidity needs. Subsequent to quarter-end, we issued $400 million of 2.25% senior notes due in 2020 and $900 million of 3.45% senior notes due in 2026. Following the issuance, we initiated the redemption of the $400 million outstanding of our December 2016 notes and the $500 million outstanding of our April 2017 notes. We also reduced our dividend by 50%, starting with the payment we made on October 3. This will provide us with over $300 million of incremental liquidity on an annual basis. Given our strong free cash flow generation, we plan to delever over time in order to preserve our investment-grade status. 
Now let's turn to some of the factors impacting fiscal 2017. For the full year, we expect that the Media Networks programming expense growth rate will be in the mid- to high single digits. In terms of Media Networks' SG&A expense, we anticipate year-over-year growth to be weighted to the first half of the year due to the timing of spend on multi-platform and data products as well as advertising and promotion expense related to the marketing of new original series. For Paramount, given the timing and mix of our films, we anticipate a higher P&A expense in the December quarter. This will result in difficult bottom line comparisons to the prior-year quarter. In terms of taxes, for 2017, we're forecasting a book tax rate of approximately 32%. We will refine this as we go through the year and get a better sense of the domestic versus international profitability mix. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Kern.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Wade. As we've discussed on prior calls, Viacom has been investing in data capabilities over the past several years. These investments in research, first-party data and advanced data science are delivering better insights and new tools across o
componenttext:
Thank you, Wade. As we've discussed on prior calls, Viacom has been investing in data capabilities over the past several years. These investments in research, first-party data and advanced data science are delivering better insights and new tools across our business. A better understanding of our fans and a more sophisticated perspective on how, when and where our content fits into their lives means better support for programming, scheduling, acquisitions, marketing and, of course, our ad sales business. 
In advertising sales, it's perhaps easiest to measure the economic impact of these advances as we can transparently benchmark against the outcomes from traditional approaches to targeting, transacting and measuring the value of television advertising. Because TV advertising has, for years, been measured only in terms of age and gender-based segments, females 18 to 34, for example, advertisers and publishers alike have had to sell, plan and deliver campaigns around metrics that do not actually match with the advertisers' true target audience. 
Because we can't communicate with precision around who an advertiser wants to reach or to whom in fact an ad was delivered, both sides of the marketplace suffer. Let's put this in concrete terms. Imagine an auto manufacturer wants to reach trucking tenders, consumers who may be in the market for a new pickup truck in the next 90 days. In the traditional currency of television, this advertiser would only be able to buy and plan against a traditional demo, like males 18 to 49. Publishers who guarantee delivery against that metric would, logically, deliver units optimized to reach those males 18 to 49 as all other impressions, a 52-year-old, for example, who might very well be actively shopping for a truck, would be considered waste and would not be appropriately valued. 
Now, however, our increasingly sophisticated use of data from multiple sources allows us to understand our audience in more detail than ever before. For the first time, it's possible to accurately identify our fans and viewers, not just by their age and gender but their income, location, brand awareness, shopping patterns, intentions and even aspirations. Ultimately, this high-resolution view of our fans and our advertisers' target audience allows us to better match advertiser campaigns with our content. This means better results for our advertisers and for our own business. 
Going back to that trucking tender we talked about. Viacom would use all available privacy-compliant data to identify households in which a truck ad could have maximum impact and we would optimize delivery against those homes. The advertiser in turn can now measure the success of the campaign and pay Viacom for those impressions that reach the actual target; not a blunt proxy based only on age and gender. 
I'd like to take a moment to talk about the infrastructure required to do this as it represents a very real and proprietary position of leadership for Viacom. We started with our first-party data management platform fueled by direct one-to-one engagement with our fans on social and digital platforms, which in total represent more than half the households in the U.S. Over the last 2 years, we've extended that reach with unique access to set-top box data from tens of millions of homes, real-time location data from hundreds of millions of mobile devices and commerce patterns from multiple sources including, but not limited to, our multiyear exclusive partnership with American Express. 
All of this data, representing literally billions of new data points, informing our perspective on the intersection of content and commerce each month, is carefully de-identified, combined and analyzed by our teams of researchers, marketers and data scientists. From the perspective of our advertisers, these improvements in audience precision and the better matching of content and viewership with their campaign yield demonstrably higher engagement and more measurable impact. Based on these results, we have seen 100% retention and steady year-over-year growth in advertiser participation. 
Further, when fewer impressions are delivered outside the intended target, those impressions that would otherwise be considered wasted for one advertiser can be intelligently allocated to other advertisers for whom they deliver real value. With television inventory fundamentally oversubscribed, every impression that is reallocated for greater impact translates directly to our bottom line. All of this has been talked about for many years, but in many cases, has lived only in the realm of theory or it was perceived to be locked up with the long-term potential of one-to-one addressable advertising. At Viacom, however, we have begun to see real results from our growing capabilities in data science as it has enabled sophisticated targeting, advanced currencies and more precise and transparent reporting of results. 
In this last upfront, Viacom wrote more than 50 deals that included Viacom Vantage, our advanced data product, which allows advertisers to target and guarantee against these new metrics. In total, the advertisers who participated in Vantage represented close to $1 billion of upfront commitments, spanning 9 key verticals and 10 major buying agencies. While some of the value unlocked in this approach will grow and show an even greater impact as the infrastructure for addressable TV matures, even today, we're seeing real value return to the marketplace through more efficient and transparent audience measurement. 
Our benchmarks demonstrate that we're unlocking measurably better outcomes for our advertisers. We're already seeing this upside in the revenue per impression delivered through Viacom Vantage. As we continue to work together with our partners in the linear television ecosystem to scale this capability across a larger portion of the dollars transacted on Viacom, that growth will continue. As we identify new ways to measure and value impressions delivered outside of the linear ecosystem, most of which go entirely unmonetized or undermonetized today, we anticipate an even greater impact on our advertising business. 
And now I'll turn it over to Bob.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kern. Before I begin, I have to say a few words of appreciation. Tom Dooley has dedicated 35 years of his life to this company as a driving force behind many of its biggest wins and a steady hand during times of transition, and most recently, p
componenttext:
Thank you, Kern. Before I begin, I have to say a few words of appreciation. Tom Dooley has dedicated 35 years of his life to this company as a driving force behind many of its biggest wins and a steady hand during times of transition, and most recently, provided assured, excellent leadership throughout the changes this year. I'm honored to be taking the handoff from him and I'm grateful for his wisdom and counsel. 
I'd also like to say thank you to Sumner, Shari, Tom May and the entire Viacom board for this amazing opportunity, but even more so, for their tireless drive to do right by Viacom. And while the board and its special committee consider whether a CBS transaction makes sense, they've asked me to maximize Viacom's potential as an independent company. And I'm committed to doing just that. 
I'm very excited about this new role and the many opportunities at hand for us. I've already pulled together the senior team across the company, and we're at work identifying near-term opportunities to accelerate our evolution while building a long-term vision for the future. At the same time, I'm reimmersing myself in the domestic business with a focus on how we can strengthen MTV, Comedy Central and Paramount. 
While we have our challenges, we also have an incredibly strong foundation from which to build. It is important to remember that Viacom has the highest share of viewing in the U.S. among all cable groups in every demo in which we compete. And worldwide, Viacom is the largest global media company by reach. We have a very strong footing. And I look forward to sharing more detailed plans on how we can build off it as soon as I can. 
But today, I want to take the opportunity to give you a bit of a window on how I think and how I operate. And the best way to do that is to look at how we've transformed Viacom International Media Networks. I joined Viacom's international business in 2007. It was at a crossroads, too focused on MTV, too dependent on the U.S. for content, too disconnected from market-to-market around the world. In the past decade, our team has addressed these issues and built a true multinational organization. We've diversified dramatically to a portfolio that includes widely distributed MTVs, Nickelodeons and Comedy Centrals, the growing Spike brand and a Paramount Channel, now the largest ad-supported movie channel in the world, and 2 key local players in the U.K.'s Channel 5 and India's COLORS. 
In 2006, MTV accounted for over 80% of our business. Today, no brand accounts for even 30%. We've become a global producer of original content, not just an exporter. We have 2,700 hours of original programming planned for 2017. And much of that consists of highly exportable formats with modest cost per episode. And we've built an organization that is interconnected across brands, businesses and geographies while fostering a culture that provides itself on entrepreneurship, innovation and adaptability. As a result, Viacom International Media Networks just closed its best year ever. 
Looking ahead, we continue to be hugely focused on scale, brands, content and products. First, scale. Our #1 priority in international is to get bigger. We've done this through organic expansion of Nickelodeon and Comedy Central globally and through the more recent international launches of Paramount Channel, Spike and Nick Jr. And we've done very well with big, mass market, general entertainment networks in priority markets. Channel 5 in the U.K. is thriving. It just delivered its most profitable year ever. And it gives Viacom the highest share of any international media company in the biggest market outside the U.S. We also have a leading position in India through our Viacom 18 joint venture, home to the COLORS brand, which is now the fastest-growing media company in the fastest-growing media market in the world. 
Second, on brands. The key word is focus. Rather than launching additional U.S. brands internationally, we focus on international core 6: MTV, Nickelodeon, Nick Jr., Comedy Central, Paramount Channel and Spike. We're investing to grow these brands while maintaining a lean, powerful portfolio that will be attractive to both pay-TV and emerging distributors, particularly virtual MVPDs. And within that footprint, we have plenty of room to grow. Comedy Central and Paramount Channel remain far less penetrated than MTV. In 2017, we already have launches planned in Central and Eastern Europe, the Middle East, Russia, Benelux, Asia and more. 
Third, on the creative side. Viacom International Media Networks' emergence as a global content engine has energized our team and strengthened our ability to localize formats. We shoot multiple versions of our biggest hits concurrently with great economics at our new studio in Miami, Channel 5 in London and production hubs in Amsterdam and Madrid. It's a formula that works. Our U.K. version of Jersey Shore, Geordie Shore, regularly beats Game of Thrones in the demo in its premiere time slot. Yes, you heard that right. Audience share for MTV, Nickelodeon and Nick Jr. is up as we localize more formats and increase international production for global use. Meanwhile, we continue to export a lot of U.S. programming, particularly via Nickelodeon, which does very well. 
Fourth and finally, products. Redefining what it means to be a branded TV network across platforms through product innovation is a huge priority for us. Pay-TV penetration outside the U.S. is well under 50%, meaning broadband growth across fixed and mobile platforms has the potential to more than double our distribution by the end of the decade. I believe this is the single biggest opportunity for our business internationally. And while the economics of digital distribution still trail linear, we believe incremental expansion of our reach will pay big returns in the long run for our brands and businesses. And last year's launch of our Viacom Play Plex suite of apps for our international brands was a big step forward in this regard. Each app features full episodes, clips on demand, along with a live linear feed. 
We tailor distribution market-by-market to reach well beyond our linear footprint. For example, we have authenticated deals with pay-TV partners in Mexico, mobile distribution with partners in Asia, our over-the-top and direct-to-consumer as we've done with BET Play in more than 100 countries -- in 100 markets worldwide where BET doesn't have a linear feed. Further, we're proving that product innovation can exist within a traditional TV environment with our personalized interactive linear channels, My Nick Jr. and My MTV. 
I believe a lot of our successful international approach can be brought home to the domestic market. I've seen it work and it's a big reason that I'm truly optimistic about Viacom. As I said earlier, I'm working with the senior management across the company to identify short-term opportunities while building on a long-term strategy. MTV is clearly a priority for me. We've had a lot of success in evolving and strengthening that brand internationally. And I'm very pleased with the recent leadership change here in the U.S. I will seek more collaborative and forward-thinking partnerships with our long-standing domestic distributors. And I'll also be working closely with Paramount. 
Finally, I'll make sure we have a structure that supports speed, sharing of resources and a global outlook. It's imperative that we operate more globally. The opportunity is there. Viacom is home to some of the world's most iconic and internationally resonant brands. I've seen what those brands and our phenomenal people can do when equipped with a focused forward-looking strategy and a strong organization from which to create and connect with millions. 
I want to thank our shareholders for their continued support and commitment to Viacom. I look forward to keeping you informed of our plans and progress. And thank you for joining today's call. I also look forward to an open dialogue. 
With that, I'll pass it back to Tom.

componenttext: This is Bob. Why don't I start? A couple of points. One is remember the big-picture perspective that we, Viacom, have the largest share of viewing of all pay-TV network companies. More specifically, if you look at our portfolio of networks and you take our top 6 networks, roughly 80% to 85% of the affiliate revenue accrues to those. And if you go to the top 8, that number goes to 90% to 95%. So even if you were to look at a scenario where you were to thin the portfolio a bit, the vast, vast majority of economics would be maintained. Second point I'd make on skinny bundles is with the -- particularly the AT&T DIRECTV announcement on their pack, skinny is not really that skinny. And we're thrilled with that deal. We believe it absolutely reflects a marketplace understanding of the value of our networks. And there, we're going to be among having the most -- the largest portfolio of networks on the platform with 11. So that, I think, is also a very strong statement. I would say, broadly speaking, this is a very exciting development in the category, OTT delivery of services and bundles of networks, particularly the ones that are pay-TV-friendly, like the ones I just discussed. It's also, by the way, a huge opportunity internationally, services like Sky NOW. And remember, international pay-TV penetration is far lower than domestic, and so it will provide a lot of upside, very exciting development for the industry for sure. In terms of the positive affiliate, yes, we are confident that we will have a return to growth in the affiliate side of the business as we move forward, even -- and particularly when you look at the domestic, even assuming a universe decline. So our guidance for fiscal Q1 of mid-single-digit 3%-ish growth assumes a 3% decline in the universe. So we will still grow even if there's a universe decline. And then internationally, again, we see significant growth. And you saw the numbers in the quarter.

componenttext: Yes. And to your second question, I really do believe it's the most significant opportunity facing not only our company but our industry today. And if I was to sum it up with one important enabler, I will use the word focus, right. And it's -- we have, through the last decade, built a true multinational organization, which has connected leadership around the world. So we're set up to execute. We have a strategy that says this is a real opportunity. And everyone, particularly on the distribution side but more broadly, is aware of that, educated on that and focused on that in our organization. And as we build, we talk about this what we call VIMN, Viacom International Media Networks, core 6. And it's about focusing our investments on content and, call it, broad marketing and promotion, including what you're doing in social and the like, on those brands so that they're as strong as possible and have a solid footing regardless of the distribution platform. Clearly, we're very focused on the MVPD space. But the good news about the VMVPD space is increasingly, these are platforms that are operated and therefore consistent with some of the philosophies that are in the -- that are built to pay-TV industry. So by focusing on it, having the right product mix, making sure your teams are really running at it, that is the key enabler because there is not a shadow of a doubt that the distribution infrastructure, particularly through mobile, will be there. And there's not a shadow of a doubt that the appetite for consumers is there. So it's really about prioritizing it and filling it.

componenttextpreview: I have one for Bob, and then one for Wade and Tom. Bob, I wonder, what's your view, philosophy on SVOD deals. And how does your thinking change versus maybe the previous administration on SVOD deals?
componenttext: I have one for Bob, and then one for Wade and Tom. Bob, I wonder, what's your view, philosophy on SVOD deals. And how does your thinking change versus maybe the previous administration on SVOD deals?

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I believe you've got to look at everything. Again, we start with we have a long history in the pay-TV business. We have deep partnerships around the world with pay-TV operators. And we believe there's incremental opportunity there. And we believe that
componenttext: So I believe you've got to look at everything. Again, we start with we have a long history in the pay-TV business. We have deep partnerships around the world with pay-TV operators. And we believe there's incremental opportunity there. And we believe that they are supportive of content businesses such as ours. So we come with a lens of looking for a pay-TV-friendly strategy. And in the last quarter, we've done a mix of deals in traditional pay. By the way, you can see that today, we announced that Spike is going 24 hours in the Netherlands with Ziggo. Ziggo is a Liberty Global company. We have a very significant relationship and partnership with Liberty Global. And they're obviously a key customer of ours. And it's a partnership that works for both of us. And I think the indication is we continue to do more things with them. That's very healthy. At the same time, on the OTT side, many of these partner -- many of these platforms increasingly are, let's use the word related, to a traditional player. The canary in the coal mine on that probably was Sky NOW in the U.K. And really all the distributors around the world, I think it's fair to say, are looking at playing in that space. Then when you look at the traditional -- traditional is a bad word, the SVOD category and you think of aggregators, we will look at that on an opportunity-by-opportunity basis, consider specifics about a market and a specific player and a specific app and determine what we want to do there. They certainly have a role in the world from a consumer perspective, but we are looking at it as part of a holistic strategy. And that will dictate what we do.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one last one for Tom or Wade. If we look at Paramount the past year and we back out that write-down, Paramount's profits still fell by over $40 million year-over-year. I wonder how much of that decline can you tie back to maybe the release
componenttext: Okay. And then one last one for Tom or Wade. If we look at Paramount the past year and we back out that write-down, Paramount's profits still fell by over $40 million year-over-year. I wonder how much of that decline can you tie back to maybe the release schedule versus other maybe systemic issues there? So can you help us try to figure out how quickly could you get back to breakeven if the movie schedule becomes more normalized, let's say?

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we'd contribute, but I think it's going to be a function of the pictures more than anything else. As I mentioned, the pictures that we have lined up in this quarter, we've already been happy with the way Jack Reacher has performed. We're very excite
componenttext: Well, we'd contribute, but I think it's going to be a function of the pictures more than anything else. As I mentioned, the pictures that we have lined up in this quarter, we've already been happy with the way Jack Reacher has performed. We're very excited about Arrival and Allied and the other 2 distribution deals that we've got teed up. And I think those are -- that's the beginning of the turnaround. The way the flow-through of the business works in terms of profitability, we have P&A upfront. The first few quarters are going to be negative. But we think that Paramount, as it gets to the back half of this year, will have very successful opportunities to begin to turn around and get back to profitability. In particular, we have this little film called Transformers 5 coming out that we have great expectations around and think it's going to be one of the biggest movies of the summer. Wade, do you want to add to that?

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the only thing -- I mean just to get back to your question, Michael. There is nothing more systemic embedded in the underperformance this year. It was really a function of the release slate in '16 and also the carryover from some of the release sl
componenttext: I think the only thing -- I mean just to get back to your question, Michael. There is nothing more systemic embedded in the underperformance this year. It was really a function of the release slate in '16 and also the carryover from some of the release slate in '15. So beyond the underperformance of the '16 slate, there is nothing systemic underlying that. And I think, as Tom said, we have a high degree of confidence in the turnaround that Paramount is getting kind of at or around breakeven.

componenttext: Best of luck to you both. You touched on this a little bit. But acknowledging there are a couple of outcomes here, can you talk a little bit more about your key priorities domestically and to what extent you'll have the ability to make decisions when and where necessary? Now as you know, one of the concerns in the market has been underinvestment in key brands, and then obviously, the complex leadership structure.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. That sounded like that was for me. So a couple of things, as I stated in my remarks, I am -- I've been chartered by the board to focus on running Viacom as an independent company. That is very much my mandate and what they've asked me to do. As part
componenttext: Sure. That sounded like that was for me. So a couple of things, as I stated in my remarks, I am -- I've been chartered by the board to focus on running Viacom as an independent company. That is very much my mandate and what they've asked me to do. As part of doing that, I believe we've got to bring the team together and unlock really what I'm convinced is a whole lot of great thinking throughout the organization and at all levels of the organization, and then identify through that the ideas we want to bring to life. When you look at it from the top-down, there's some clear weakness areas, as we've talked about, MTV. Comedy Central, we have some recent good trend lines in Trevor. By the way, Trevor Noah is significantly stronger internationally than Jon was. So the Trevor Noah franchise is a great one. And the fact that he's really connecting through this election cycle is a very exciting development. And also South Park's 20th, 20-year-old franchise and the new episodes are doing extremely well. And that's another global franchise. So there's some good stuff starting to happen at Comedy Central. And obviously, we'd like to see more happen. On the Paramount side, as Tom and Wade indicated and I've been speaking with Brad regularly and just starting to get into that, obviously the film slate will be highly important. We're also going to see what we can do on the marketing side in the short term to see if that is an incremental opportunity. So I think there's a clear set of priorities and I'm convinced that by working with the team, we will unlock a good action plan. Obviously, part of that will be content investments. But I think it's important that based on -- you understand that based on my experience, a lot of this is about mix of investments, not about you have to spend dramatically more money necessarily. Again, our international experience shows that you can deliver very significant audiences in genres other than high-dollar scripted programming. So I think mix will continue to be an opportunity.

componenttext: And we think a lot of the other -- and arguably the guidance that we've talked about here today factors in the other elements that you mentioned, and as Bob mentioned and reinforced, a low mid-single-digit decline in universe estimate. So we've had good negotiations and good relations with all of our distributors. Our deals go far out into the future. And we feel that we're in good shape to resume affiliate fee growth in 2017.

componenttextpreview: I think it's for Bob and Tom. Just wanted to drill into the Paramount situation a little more. If I'm hearing you correctly, you think that the slate, upcoming slate will lead to profitability late in fiscal '17. But I was wondering if you look back at wh
componenttext: I think it's for Bob and Tom. Just wanted to drill into the Paramount situation a little more. If I'm hearing you correctly, you think that the slate, upcoming slate will lead to profitability late in fiscal '17. But I was wondering if you look back at what happened over the past several years, the deterioration in earnings there, do you think there is -- there needs to be a change in how the greenlighting process probably works? Because the industry press says that the studio management says that there was underinvestment, which is hard to sort of believe when you look at production budgets. So I was wondering if you could reconcile those for us.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think that the pictures that we put into production over the past several years, we had several big pictures that underperformed dramatically relative to what we had thought they would do. A good example of that is Zoolander. Another example of th
componenttext: Look, I think that the pictures that we put into production over the past several years, we had several big pictures that underperformed dramatically relative to what we had thought they would do. A good example of that is Zoolander. Another example of that is Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Those films really had losses that were outsized and really created the hole in the bucket that we had in the previous year, consequential hole in the bucket. And I think we have looked at the greenlight process. I think Brad Grey and his team, he's made changes on his team and is focused on putting in place the kind of movies that we think will result in a significant turnaround and refocused on bottom line profitability and the type of movies that he's putting into production. And as I said, as we look down the road here and I think as we get through the end of this quarter, you'll see Paramount having a much better performance in the pictures that it's putting into the marketplace. And I think the most important thing to look for is how they perform relative to the competition. Then I think you'll see Paramount beginning to stand up and distinguish itself in that regard.

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext: Do you feel that there was underinvestment in Paramount's films?

headline: Viacom, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think we can debate that all day long. I think that the films that were put into production obviously had -- I think the commentary would be, "Did we invest in things like Marvel or other big acquisitions like some of our competitors did?" Obvious
componenttext: Look, I think we can debate that all day long. I think that the films that were put into production obviously had -- I think the commentary would be, "Did we invest in things like Marvel or other big acquisitions like some of our competitors did?" Obviously, those were sound acquisitions and worked out well for them. I'm not so sure those would have worked out in a similar way for Viacom and nor do we have the financial resources to make those kind of investments at that point in time. So I'm not going to debate the level of investment and history because it doesn't pay to look back and hypothesize as to what it would have been.
